No, I am confident of that—they could not go there without my knowing it, unless I was asleep—I was not asleep before, that evening—there are not two entrances to the bed-room—the entrance is in the passage, it is not necessary to go into the kitchen to go to the bed-room.

SUSANNAH WOODWARD . I am servant to Mrs. Barkley—on the 17th of July, about ten o'clock in the evening, or a few minutes before, Gill and Jones came to the house together—Gill said to me, what will you have—I said nothing—she said, "Have something"—I said, "If I have something you must fetch it"—she fetched spirits and some half-and-half, which we drank together—we all four partook of it—they went out together and returned in about half an hour—about eleven o'clock they said, "What will you have to drink"—somebody said brandy—and Mrs. Barkley herself fetched half a pint,2s. worth, from the public-house—it was mixed by Gill and Jones—a person called me to the street-door, and when I came back mistress had a glass by the side of her—she drank some of it and said How sweet it was—Gill gave me a glass in the kitchen—I said, "Jane, what have you put in this brandy"—she said, "Nothing"—I swallowed a good mouth full of it, and chucked the rest away"—I was sitting in the chair and went fast to sleep—I did not see them go out to go to bed—Mistress awoke me about six o'clock, saying "Susan, I am robbed"—! suid, "Who has robbed you"—she said "Bulley, Jane"—my

mistress usually sleeps in the back room, on the same floor as the kitchen—it opens into the passage—when I went to sleep the outer door was open—I found it shut in the morning—mistress opened it herself—I saw this candle
stick found in my mistress's bed-room.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. You did not see what candlesticks they took 1A. No—this candlestick was on the kitchen-table with a candle in it before I went to sleep—we have only this one candlestick of the kind in the house, the others are very large brass ones—we have another Ten large tin one which is very seldom used—my mistress took as much half-and-half and gin as we all did—that did not make us tipsy—I drank a good mouthful of the brandy-and-water—I threw a good drop of it into the coal. hole—I dare say a gill—it was bitter and sweet, both—it was very nasty-there was no brandy-and-water left in the morning—I did not see what my mistress drank—I never saw my mistress with these spectacles, but can swear to the other things—I did not let in so many as half a dozen people that evening.

ELIZABETH BARKLEY
re-examined. When I awoke in the morning, the brandy-and-water that I had left was chucked away—I did not chuck it away.

MARY ANN MARTIN . I am an unfortunate girl, and live in Rupert-street. On Friday night, the 17th of July, about a quarter to ten o'clock, I wasatthe Garrick tavern, and saw the three prisoners and another man drinking—they all four crossed the road, and went into a public-house opposite—I went there and saw them—I heard Webb say to Gill, "Will you haveany more drink"—she said, "No"—I heard her say, Where shall I meet you"—I did not hear the answer—I saw Gill and Jones together again about a quarter to two o'clock that night, going up Christopher-court, Rupert-street, near Mrs. Barkley's Howe—Jones had something square carrying by the side of him, wrapped up in something dark, with one corner hanging down—they were going out of Ru
pert-street, going in a direction from Mrs. Barkley's house, and not above three minutes' walk from it—they were both together—I was standing at Mrs. Smith's door, No. 1, Christopher-court—there was a gas-light opposite—Mrs. Smith goes by the name of Bowner—I have no doubt of the prisoners Jones and Gill being the parties—Jones had a black band round his hat, very broad, and I knew Gill before.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BBIBN. Q. Had you seen Jones before that evening? A. Yes—they went risjht before me up the court, as I stood at the door—I am living with Mrs. Barkley now—I was not then—after I was examined I went to live there, and am there still.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where is the Garrick tavern. A. Ie Leman-street, Whitechapel—Cox's is opposite—when Jones and Gill went away and said "Good night, "Webb and the other man remained at the public-house—I had seen Jones three weeks before, coming out of the Lon
don docks—he told me he was a foreman in the docks—he did not speak te me when I saw him in the public-house.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Were you ever taken up on uy charge? A. No.

MR. BALDWIN. Q. Is it unusual for a girl in your situation to live in one house more than another? A. No, I do not often move about, but my landlady was in the hospital, and I staid there till she was better.

SUSANNAH WOODWARD
re-examined. I did not notice Jones' hat that night.
ELIZABETH BOWNER . I live in Christopher-court, Rupert-street. Ontw 17th of July, about a quarter before two o'clock, I saw a man dressed in dark

clothes come by the door, and saw Gill, with a man dressed in dark clothes, come oat of Mrs. Barkley's house—she drew the door to after her—I saw it was shut to—I cannot say it was fastened—they came out together—I saw nothing with them—their backs were towards me—I do not know the man—I saw Gill's face—I had seen her before, and known her by sight very well for a long time.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. How far were you from them? A. Within one house of them—they came out of No. 1, Rupert-street—I was opposite No. 3—I followed them because they were going the same way as I was—they went up the court, and I lived up the court—I went into my own door, and saw no more of them—they were in the court when I entered it.

CHARLES DORKMAN . I live in Tollington-street, Whitechapel-road. On Friday night, the 17th of July, between twelve and one o'clock, I saw Webb, just by Whitechapel-pump, going towards Rupert-street, about two minutes' walk from it—I knew him—he asked me to have a pint of beer, and I refused—he and Gill lived at my mother's at the time.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did not he say, "Holloa, Charley, How are you?" A. Yes, and asked me to have half a pint of beer.

AMELIA SCARLETT . I am single, and have been staying some time with Mrs. Dorkman—I knew the prisoners Webb and Gill. On Saturday, the 18th of July, between four and five o'clock in the morning, I saw them at the Blue Anchor public-house, Whitechapel-road, drinking half-and-half—that is not more than a quarter of a mile from Rupert-street—I left them there—I had been staying at Dorkman's about a fortnight.

ELIZABETH DORKMAN . I live in Thomas-street, and let apartments—tha prisoners Webb and Gill lived three weeks with me, as man and wife. On Saturday morning, the 18th of July, about five o'clock, they both came boms together.

HENRY BOARD . I am a cow-keeper, and live in Lipman-street, Cambridge-road. I found this cash-box in my cow-yard, which is three or four minutes' walk from Thomas-street—I do not know How far from Rupert-street—my yard is in the high road—the box was open—there was an ear-drop in it.

THOMAS KELLY (police-constable H 119.) On the day of the robbery I apprehended the prisoners Webb and Gill, at Mrs. Dorkman's house—I told them they were charged with stealing money, but I did not know the particu
lars at the time—Webb said he knew nothing about it, he was quite ready to go—Gill said, "Is that the charge?"—I said I could not exactly tell her the charge, she would know it at the station—I received the cash-box from the inspector, and the ear-drops—I apprehended Jones on Saturday week, walk
ing in the Whitechapel-road—I told him the charge—he said I must be mis
taken, he knew nothing about it—I searched him at the station, and found a sovereign, 5s. 6d. in silver, three farthings, and these spectacles and case—he requested to have the spectacles back, but I would not give them to him—he refused to tell me where he lived—he said twice that the spectacles were of no use to me, and wanted them back, but Mrs. Barkley was asked whether she had lost any spectacles—she said she had, and if they were hers the right sight was broken—she said that before she saw them—I had not seen them myself—she said the right side was cracked—I know Board's cow-yard—it is three quarters of a mile from Rupert-street, and three or four minutes' walk from 1 hornas-street—beyond Thomas-street, coming from Rupert-street.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. When did you see Mrs. Barkley after the robbery? A. Not till the prisoners were at the station—I heard nothing then about any spectacles, not until they were taken from Jones—Mrs. Barkley was asked if she had lost a pair—she said she had a pair, and if

she had lost them, if they were hers, the right sight was cracked—I appre
hended Jones about a quarter of a mile from Rupert-street, at half-past eleven at night.
MR. O'BRIEN, on behalf of Jones and Gill, called

JAMES BOOTH . I am a working-jeweller, and live with my employer, Afo, Sumner, in Church-row, Houndsditch. I remember repairing a pair of spec
tacles for the prisoner Jones.

COURT. Q. Have you been in Court during this trial? A. Only about two minutes—I do not know who brought me in—he is somebody's clerk, I believe—he has something to do with this case—he brought me in to show me the spectacles—I do not know How he knew who to apply to—that is the person—(pointing him out)—he showed them to me, and asked if I could identify my own work—I said, "Yes,"and after seeing them I went out of Court—my attention was called to part of the bridge of the spectacles, which has I been broken—one of the glass places had been broken off—I recollect mending them, because I can tell my own workmanship—Mr. Jones, the prisoner's brother, I believe is the person who found me out—he subpœnaed me—I do not see him in Court—Mrs. Sumner carries on the jewellery trade—she is not here.

MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Look at these spectacles—(looking at them.) A. I believe I can safely say I mended these—it must be eight months ago—I know them because I generally mend them with brass solder—here is the J mark—I had not mended other spectacles for the prisoner, that I am aware I of—I charged him 6d. for these—he paid it to Mrs. Sumner—I did not I know him before, but I recollect his countenance—Mrs. Sumner is not here. I

Cross-examined by MR. BALDWIN. Q. You live where you are employed? A. Yes, I am a journeyman, and live in the house—I swear that—some per
sons use silver solder to mend steel spectacles—I have not mended any but I with brass solder, since it has been found to be better—I have mended spec
tacles for three or four years—I cannot say How many pairs I have mended I in Mrs. Summer's employment.
JURY. Q. How is it this spot is not blue? A. You cannot blue that—I we do not blue them all over—the glasses were not broken when I mended I them, that I am aware of.
MR. BALDWIN. Q. Do you mean, by looking at this piece of solder, tony I it is your own work and no one else's? A. I can tell my own workmanship.

Q. Has not this mark been made in the same way—(handing him another pair)? A. I believe it has—it is not my work—it is mended neater thin 1 I should do it—nobody else mends with brass solder—I never heard of it—I I mended these—I do not know that the prisoner left any name with them—I they were repaired while he waited—it was in the winter and was about the I middle of the day—Mrs. Sumner was present in the shop, no one else—I mentioned to her that I was coming here—I called her attention to what I was coming for—it is seldom I repair spectacles.

MR. BALDWIN. Q. Did you ever see the prisoner before that time, on your oath? A. No—I remember the last pair I repaired there—Jones's bro
ther first came to me about this—I did not know him before—he said called to know if I recollected mending a pair of spectacles some time ago for a young man who waited for them—I asked How long it was since—he said, "About eight months,"and then I called to mind that I did do a pair—I have not had any money from the prisoner's brother or from the attorney in this case—he told me his brother was in trouble, and told me I was wanted if I could identify the spectacles I repaired for the young man—he told mew was charged with stealing them—he said he wanted me to identify the person

and the spectacles—he did not describe the man who had left them, he only uid he was a tallish man—he did not tell me How he was dressed—I did not look at the dock when I came in here to see the spectacles—I did not look where the prisoner is standing—I had not seen him from the time I mended the spectacles till I saw him here—I had not seen him in custody—this is the eighth day I have been waiting here—I cannot say why I did not look at the bar—I have turned my head and seen him several times since I have been here—I did not look at his face when I came in, because I knew I should know the man—I did not give it a thought to look at him when I came—I cannot exactly say it is eight months since I repaired the specta
cles—I will swear it is a month—I did not make an entry in the books of the job.
FRANCIS EVANS . I am waiter at the King and Queen public-house, Mile-end-road. I know the prisoner Jones—he is iu the habit of wearing blue steel spectacles.

COURT. Q. Was there anything remarkable about them? A. The right glass was broken—he wore them in that state—I have not been in Court—I was applied to to prove this last week—I think the right glass was cracked across the centre, perpendicularly—he frequently wore them in reading.

MR. BALDWIN. Q. Tell us any time you have seen him wearing blue steel spectacles with a crack? A. Several times—the last time was four or five mcmths ago—I am a waiter—I worked in the docks before that—1 have not been in trouble—the prisoner did not work in the docks to my knowledge—Idid not know him at the docks—I do not know How he gets his livelihood—I do not know him more than seeing him at my master's house—I was brought here last Wednesday—the friends of the prisoner came to me.

COURT. Q. Did he come into the public-house wearing the spectacles) or take them out of his pocket and put them on? A. I have seen him take them out of his pocket, take them out of a black case, I think, and put them on—it wai not a new case—I cannot swear to the case—I can to the spectacles—these are the spectacles—(looking at them)—I know them by this crack—I have bad them in my hand four or five months ago in the public-house—he did not take them off and hand them to me—they were lying on the table when he was done reading the paper—I took them up and said, "Are these yours?"and gave them to him—I do not know whether he put them into his pocket.

COURT to ELIZABETH BARKLEY. Q. Take the spectacles in your hand—had you noticed any join about one of the eyes? A. It is here—I had tried them on to see if they suited me, and they did not—I merely noticed the way the glass was broken—I did not notice the little join and the brass—I bad them, to the best of my knowledge, abput ten months—they were left at my house by accident—I had not seen Jones, to my knowledge, before the night he came with Gill—he could not be the person who left them—the case is the same, except a piece has been torn off—I know the spectacles by the broken glass.
SAMUEL TAYLOR . I am street-keeper of Whitechapel—the prosecutrix's house is in the parish of St. Mary, Whitechapel.

GILL—
GUILTY . Aged 28.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

WEBB—
NOT GUILTY .

1697.
STEPHEN MATTHEWS was indicted
for unlawfully assaulting
Sarah Griffiths, with intent, &c.

GUILTY of an Assault .—
Confined Three Months, fined 5l .
and to enter into recognizances, &c.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
1698.
SAMUEL WILES was indicted
for stealing 2s., the monies of
William James Harris, his master.

WILLIAM JAMES HARRIS . I am a cheesemonger, and live in Charles-street, Back-road, St. George in the East—the prisoner was in my service—in consequence of suspicion, on the 13th of August, I marked five shillings, and put them into my till about five or six o'clock—I went about seven o'clock, and found them safe there—I then marked two more shillings and a sixpence, and put them in the till—about eight o'clock I went to tie till, and missed one of the shillings—I then took the sixpence out, and left the six marked shillings in the till—I sent the prisoner over to the ware-house—he came back, and I went into the parlour at the back of the shop—I watched, and saw two children come in for half a pound of butter—they gave him a shilling, and he gave them sixpennyworth of halfpence in return, which he took from the till—there was plenty of copper in the till, but do silver but what was marked—I directly went into the shop, and there was bat five shillings in the till—there ought to have been seven—I took the pri
soner by the collar and said, "What have you done with the two shillings you have just taken out of the till?"—he trembled very much—I pushed him into the parlour—he said he knew nothing about it—I told him I certainly should send for a policeman—he then said he would give it me back if I would for give him—I said, "I told you I was robbed a few weeks ago by the last boy, and you knew Tery well what I intended to do with the next I caught"—k said, "Pray forgive me on account of my mother"—I gave him into custody, and two shillings were shaken out of his boot—one was marked—the other was not—this is one I had marked with a scratch on the top of the crown.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How many shillings have you marked 1A. I never marked any before—I did not state before the Magis
trate that I marked six shillings—I marked five shillings first, and two shil
lings and a sixpence afterwards—this is my signature to this deposition—I did not say I marked six shillings, and put them into the till, where there was no other but copper money—this was read over to me, but not about the six shillings—I was watching the prisoner all day—I had a good opportunity of seeing what be did.

COURT. Q. are you sure you marked five shillings at five o'clock? between five and six o'clock—about eight I found the five shillings right—i then put in two shillings and a sixpence more marked—i sent the prisoner to the warehouse, and about nine o'clock the children came, and gave him a id-ling—shortly after I missed two shillings, and two shillings were found in in boot—one was marked, the other was not.

ROBERT BOARD (police-constable K 232.) I was called on the night of the 13th of Aug. to take the prisoner—I told him Mr. Harris charged him with robbing him—he begged him to forgive him for the sake of his mother—I found two shillings, five pence, and a farthing, in his trowsers pocket, and in his boot two shillings, one marked, and the other not—he begged Mr. Harris to forgive him.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1699.
AUGUSTUS PHIPPS was indicted for
stealing 1 coat, value 21. 4s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 14s.; 1 waistcoat, 9; 2 handkerchiefs, 5 and 3 half-crowns; the property of
Henry Joseph Bligh; and
SAMUEL WHICHELOW ,
for feloniously receiving 1 coat, 1 waistcoat, and 1 pair of trowsers, part of the same, knowing them to have been stolen.

HENRY JOSEPH BLIGH . I live in Dorset-street, Marylebone—I am some-times known by the name of Harry Messenger—I work for Mr. Messenger, a greengrocer. On Saturday night, the 25th of July, I went to my brother's, in Compton-street—I was walking, about nine o'clock that night, in Compton-court, with Amelia Knox—we met the prisoners and George Tibbey at Leices
ter-square—we all went together towards my residence—when we got to South-street, Phipps said, "There is my aunt"—I said, "Where?"—I looked round, but could not see her, and Phipps was then out of my sight—Whichelow then said, "We will have some porter"—we went into a public-house, and staid there about ten minutes—I then went borne—Whichelow wanted me to stop, but I would not—he, Tibbey, and Knox, went home with me, and I found the area grating open—I said, "Oh, my God 1 the place has been robbed"—I went down to the kitchen, where I live—the things were very much displaced, and I could not stand, I was so giddy—I do not know what made me so—I did not miss anything on that occasion, but about two o'clock on Sunday, the next day, I missed my coat, waistcoat, a pair of trow
sers, and 7s. 6d., which had been in my waistcoat pocket—I saw the prisoners that day, and told them I had been robbed—they said, "Oh, have yoa? who do you suspect"—I said, "I don't know who to suspect"—Whichelow said, "Do you think it is Dudley Moore?"—I said, "I don't know"—he said, "We will go and see"—Phipps and Whichelow went to see—I went to the station and gave information—Phipps came to me, and said Dudley Moore had plenty of money, and he had not been at work that day—I went with the policeman, and took both the prisoners—in coming along Oxford-street, Phipps said, "I will get you the clothes back for 8.; they are sold at Mrs. Bateman's, and I will give you 10s. to say nothing about it"—I said, "It is not in my hands now, it is in the constable's; I cannot do anything with it"—just before we got to the station, Phipps said, "Will you—now or never?"—I knew both the prisoners—Whichelow was in my employ—I had some goats and chaises—he used to go out with them.

Cross-examined by MR. NATLOE. Q. Do not people call you Messenger always 1A. No—some people do, because I have been at work so long for Messenger—I was robbed about five years ago—I do not often have tricks played with me—I have seen Phipps's aunt—I could not see her that night—I was not tipsy—we had one pot of porter—I then went to Dorset-street—I did not go to bed—I was lying by the side of the bed when I awoke, about half-past seven o'clock the next morning—I did not suspect Dudley Moore of stealing my things before—he is not a friend of mine—I know him very well—Phipps said the things were sold at Mrs. Bateman's—she is not here—she was at Marylebone office—Phipps said he could get my clothes back for 8.—he did not say he could get them of Tibbey—the prisonersere on intimate terms with me—we never went out and walked together.
COURT. Q. You found the area grate open? A. Yes—I had left home about half-past seven o'clock—it was then shut down close—I went back about twenty minutes before eleven o'clock.

THOMAS SKINNER (police-constable D 102.) On Saturday, the 25th of July, I saw the prisoners walking together, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, in Mortimer-street, Portland-place—Whichelow had a bundle under his arm—I saw Knox and Tibbey about thirty yards behind the prisoners—I followed them, and lost sight of them at the bottom of Mortimer-street—I took both the prisoners on Monday morning—I took Phipps first—he said

he did not know anything about it—as we were going along Oxford-street with the prosecutor, I heard Phipps say he would give him 8. to get the clothes back, and 10s. on the Saturday night to say nothing about it—the prosecutor said, "you did not care what you did to me, and I don't care what I do to you; it is in the officer's hands"—just before we got to the station door, I heard Phipps say, "Now is your time, or never"—Whichelow said, "1 shall speak the truth."

Cross-examined. Q. Did not Phipps say, "Now is your time, or never, to get your clothes back from Tibbey A. I did not hear that—he might have said it—I am quite sure he said he would give the prosecutor 8s. to get the clothes back.

MR. EVANS. Q. Tell me the precise words you overheard Phipps make use of? A. He said he would give him 85. to get the clothes back, and, on the Saturday night if he would say nothing about it—it might be that he would get the clothes back.

GEORGE TIBBEY . On Saturday night, the 25th of July, I was with the prisoners, the prosecutor, and Knox—Phipps left in South-street—he said, "There is my aunt"—I did not see his aunt—the rest of us went in a public-house—we stopped ten minutes—we then went towards the prosecutor's—we left him next door to his residence—in about ten minutes I saw Phipps with a bundle—he said it was the prosecutor's clothes—I did not hear anything then about selling them—we waited about ten minutes in Dorset-street to see if the prosecutor would come out again, which he had promised, but he did not—we then went on towards Hopkins's-street—Whichelow carried the bundle—he was with Phipps, and I was about twenty yards behind with Knox—I saw Whichelow at a door-way in Hopkins's-street—we all went on, and Whichelow came after us and asked if 8s. would do for the clothes—Phipps said yes, as he could not take them home—Whichelow went back and brought the money—he gave it to Phipps—he said he had 6.—I did not I see it—Phipps 'gave back to Whichelow two half-crowns and a sixpence—I then I received half-a-crown from Whichelow.

Cross-examined. Q. What had you the half-crown for? A. My share—I did not assist in stealing them—I knew they were to be stolen some time I before—I was bound to come here to-day—I came to forward the ends of I justice, not to save myself—I did not steal bread and candles—I did not I work at a candle-maker's—I know Knox very well—she gets her living by I washing—nothing else that I am aware of—she lives with her mother—she I never lived with me

AMELIA KNOX . I live in Pulteney-court. I remember Saturday night, I the 25th of July—I was with the prosecutor and Tibbey in South-street—we I went into a public-house and came out about ten o'clock—I afterwards saw I Phipps in Dorset-street with a bundle—he said they were the prosecaton I clothes—he took them a little away, and then gave them to Whichelow—they went to Hopkins-street—I saw Whichelow stand at a door-way in Hop—I kins-street—Phipps stood at the next door—Tibbey and I walked on—I Phipps came soon after, and Whichelow came and said would 8s. do—Phipps I said, "Yes"—W'hichelow went back and brought 6.—that was divided I between the three—Bligh is sometimes called Harry Messenger—about iff I weeks ago I heard Whichelow say he intended to get the prosecutors clothes.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you go on to Pulteney-court? A. Yes—I there—Tibbey went to see me home—he did not go in with me—he I fancy man"—I do not support him—I do not know whether I do everything I else for him—I did not know that these things were to be stolen, only what
Whichelow said to Tibbey—we only staid in a public-house two of three minutes while a pot of beer was drank—Tibbey did not have the clothe—he bad half-a-crown of the money.

PHIPPS—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

WHICHELOW—
GUILTY . Aged 20

1700.
MARY COSTER was indicted
for stealing 5 shirts, value 2l.; 1 blanket, 2s.; 1 coat, 10.; 1 scarf, 2.; and 1 fork, 6d.; the goods of
Charles Butcher, her master.

CAROLINE BUTCHER . I am the wife of Charles Butcher, of Cheynes-street, Tottenham Court-road. The prisoner was in my employ about two months—the last time was about six weeks ago—I employed her as a char-woman, to light the fire and clean the place—the last time she was there I missed a sovereign—shortly before her leaving I missed two shirts—I dis-charged my other servant because I thought she was dis
honest—the next time I saw the prisoner after she left, I went to ask her to come to cook a supper—she was in liquor, and her husband would not let her come—she ran away from her husband—on the 15th of Aug. I saw her—she said, "Mrs. Butcher, How do you do?"—I said, "Very well, you are the person I want"—she first seized me by the neck, she then let go her hold and ran up stairs—I followed her, and sent for a policeman, and gave her into custody-next day I searched her premises with the policeman—I found a shirt on her husband's back, marked with my husband's name—I found a coat hanging up which I had not missed, and a black scarf in a band-box, a fork, and a blanket on the bed—they are my husband's—I had not given the prisoner any of these things—this is the coat—these are my articlet.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR. Q. This is an old coat? A. Yes—my husband worked about in the house in it—I know the shirt by the name on it—it is old, but it is of use—I was married at Northampton—I have not been married twice—I have been married to Mr. Butcher between three and four years—I have never been separated from him—I had not em
ployed any person but the prisoner as a charwoman—I gave her the gown she has on now, and a bed-quilt—I have sold furniture to Mr. King, a broker, with my husband's permission—I believe the prisoner lives with Mr. King—my husband has not been in the habit of selling things—I have not given anything away within six months—I gave her three blankets to wash, which came home—this shirt is the worst that was found.

MR. PARNELL. Q. At the time this shirt was missed other shirtawere missed? A. Yes, four—they were good ones—this is an old one—my hus
band was not before the Magistrate—the prisoner stated that I gave her the things—if Mr. Butcher had sold either clothes or furniture to Mr. King I should have known of it.

' MR. MELLOR. Q. There was some quarrel between you and the prisoner? A. Yes—I went to her house—she has not been living with her husband ever since she left me—I went after her several times—the door was always locked—shewas away for six weeks from her lodging.
WILLIAM WILLIS (police constable E 64.) I took the prisoner—I went with Mr. Butcher the next morning to the prisoner's lodgings, and found these articles.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.—
Confined Three Months.

1701.
JOHN HIGH , was indicted
for assaulting
Emma Henty with in
tent, &c.
NOT GUILTY .

1702.
THOMAS CHURCH and
JOHN BROWN were indicted for
steal
ing 1 watch, value 1l., the goods of
Sarah Smith.

SARAH SMITH . I am a widow, and live at Leytonstone. On the 11th of July I left my watch in the parlour about one or two o'clock—I was absent from the room about five minutes—when I came back the watch was gone—the window was open—this is my watch.

WILLIAM FRAZER . On the 11th of July, between one and two o'clock, I saw the two prisoners near the chapel pump, at Leytonstone—I saw Brown come out of Mrs. Smith's gate—Church was on the other side of the road—he could see Mrs. Smith's house—Brown took something out of his pocket, and showed it to Church, and then they went away—I described the boys.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Had Brown any poultry with him? A. No—he had no basket—you go through a gate to the house.

SAMUEL BUTLER BAKER . I am an engineer. I received information of this loss, and a description of the boys from Frazer—I went across the forest, and saw the prisoners—I followed them a short distance—I went and found this watch in a spot near to where I saw the prisoners.

RICHARD LAMB . I saw the two prisoners together after this loss—they were sitting down at a corner near where the watch was found—I saw then about an hour and a half after the robbery, and the watch was found within two hours.

CHURCH—
GUILTY . Aged 17.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Three Months ,

1703.
JOHN WINCH was indicted
for stealing 1 half-sovereign, to money of
George Paine; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months ,

1704.
HARRIET GRIFFIN was indicted
for stealing 4lbs. weight of pork, value 2s., the goods of
John Barnes.

JOHN BARNES . I live at Stratford, in Essex, and sell pork. On Satur
day, the 18th of July, I saw the prisoner inside my shop about nine o'clock at night—she inquired the price of pork—she looked out a piece, as I sup
posed, with the intention of having it weighed—she did not buy anything, to my knowledge—I made a motion to my lad to look after her—she left the shop, and in consequence of information I sent for a policeman—she no brought back to my house, and the policeman produced the pork—I knew it by some discolouration on the top of the rind—it was the outside piece, tw had got stained—I told the prisoner she had got into a bad mess, and w offered to pay me for it.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What was the weight ofrt—A. I do not know exactly—it was worth more than 2s.—I have known w prisoner two years by coming to my shop—I frequently suspected her has bought things, and paid for them—there were a good many customers—this was the piece of pork the prisoner was inquiring about.

HENRY LAMBERT . I am in the prosecutor's service. The prisoner came to the shop and asked the price of a piece of pork—I showed her a piece, and told her the price was 6 1/2 d. a pound, and I would weigh it outside—she was inside the shop—I told her to bring it out—she brought it out, and walked away with it—I made some inquiry of my master—I went, but could not see her—I got a policeman, and went to Forrest-gate, where she lives—the po
liceman went in, and came out with her—I saw the pork—it was the same piece I hadshown her—she was brought back, and she said she would pay my roaster for it.
JOSEPH BENTON (police constable K 381.) I went after the prisoner to her house—her daughter sent for her—she was not at home—I found this piece of pork.
GEOROIANA UPTON . I was assisting Mr. Barnes that night—I did not take the money for this pork.
NOT GUILTY .

1705.
JOHN LARKINS and
ANTHONY BARRETT were indicted for
stealing 1 coat, value 10., the goods of
James Pincott Cornwall Reynolds.

JANE REYNOLDS. I am the wife of James Pincott Cornwall Reynolds, of Leyton in Essex. On the 3rd of Aug. I saw the two prisoners in the hall of our house—they had no business there—Larkins took my husband's coat and ran away—Barrett did not come in, he stood on the steps—Larkins went to him with the coat, and they ran away together—they dropped it in the garden.
Larkins. It was not me took it. Witness. I am quite sure of his person.
MARY WOODFORD . I saw the prisoners going over the gate—I am quite sore they are the two persons.
Larkins Defence. A person was standing at Mr. Reynolds's gate; the bell was broken; he asked me to get over, which I did; the coat was near the door, I did not touch it; it was Charley Evans took it.
(Larkins received a good character.)

LARKINS—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Two Months

BARRETT—
GUILTY . Aged l6.—
Confined Four Months.

1706.
JAMES LANGFORD was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM BANKS . I live in New-row, Deptford, and deal in fire-wood—the prisoner was in my service—it was his duty to make bundles of wood, and to go out with it occasionally, and receive money for the wood when be sold it—on the 17th of July I sent him out with wood—his own boy went out with him, with a horse and cart—the boy came back with the horse and cart—the prisoner did not return—he was taken on the 31of July—taought to have returned on the evening of the 17th of July, and if he had received any money he was to pay it the same night, when he came home—he was to sell the wood by the hundred—if he got more than the price I charged he was to keep that to himself—the wood I sent him with that day was worth 1l. 16s. 9 1/2 d.—I produce a note which he sent to me when he was taken—some man brought it to me—I do not know the writing.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not lend me the horse and cart? A. No.
EDWARD JONES . I am in Mr. Banks' employ. On Friday the 17th of I went out with the prisoner—he had Mr. Banks's horse and cart, with
fourteen hundred of wood—we went to sell it—I sold seven hundred of it, and he sold seven hundred—I saw him receive some of the money, not all—I saw him receive 5s. 4d., 5s. 6d., and 2s. 4d.

WILLIAM THOMAS ARTHUR (police-constable R 202.) I took the prisoner on the evening of the 30th of July—I said, "Langford you must go to the station with me"—he said, "What about?"—I said, "Respecting a load of wood of Mr. Banks's"—he said, "That is all settled"—I said, "I have not understood that, you must go with me."

Prisoner's Defence. He lent me the horse and cart, and trusted me with the wood; I had the misfortune to lose half the money, and I could not make it up; I sent the letter and said I would come back and pay him 6s. a week till I had paid it.

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Confined Four Months.

1707.
FREDERICK WARD was indicted
for stealing 3 pairs of trowsers, value 3l. 10s.; and 2 1/2 yards of woollen cloth, 1l. 2.; the goods of
George Tabret Lock, and another; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE TABRET LOCK . I am a tailor, and live in Woolwich—I had some trowsers in my shop on the 22nd of July—I missed them—I went I with Samuel Watts on board a Waterman steam-packet at a little after one o'clock—I went into the cabin and saw the prisoner—he had two paper parcels—Watts opened them—they contained these three pairs of trowaen, which I can swear to as mine—this pair is my apprentice's make, they are all the property of me and my son, who is partner with me—this piece of cloth I cannot swear to, but a piece was missing from my shop, which was brought in the night before for a customer.

Prisoner. Q. What can you swear to the trowsers by? A. This pair I can swear to by taking in three-eighths of an inch at the bottom; and these I black ones, this was a remnant of kerseymere, and they are my making—I they are all my making, or the apprentice's.

ROBERT MORRISON . I am apprentice to Mr. Lock—about one o'clock on 1 the 22nd of July I came up to my dinner and saw the prisoner in the shop—I I asked if he wanted to see Mr. Lock, he said, "No, I have seen him"—I did I not know whether he had seen him or not—I left him there.

SAMUEL WATTS . I am parish constable of Woolwich—I went on board I the Waterman steam-packet, which was coming to London, between one I and two o'clock on the 22nd of July, and in the cabin, I saw the prisoner I tying up a paper parcel—he had another parcel with him—I found in one I parcel these two pairs of trowsers, and in the other this piece of cloth, and I these other trowsers—I asked whose they were—he said his—I asked where I he got them—he said he bought them—I called the prosecutor, he identified I them.

GEORGE HARRIS (police-constable R 158.) I produce a certificate of the I prisoner's former conviction at this Court—(read—Convicted 24th Nov. 1845, and confined three months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1708.
WILLIAM PITCHER and
HERBERT GRAHAM were in
dicted for
stealing 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch-guard, 5.; 1 watch-chain,35.; and 2 seals, 2.; the goods of
George Small, from his person.

GEORGE SMALL . I am a wheelwright, and live in Southampton-mews, Euston-square. About two o'clock in the day, on the 4th of Aug., I was at Woolwich—I had had a pint of stout on board the vessel I went down in—was a little in liquor—I recollect going into a public-house—I do not know How long I was there—I think I must have gone in about three o'clock—I had

about seven half-crowns in my pocket, a chain round my neck, and a watch in my fob, and two seals—I am sure they were safe when I went into the public-house—the prisoner Pitcher came in after me—I do not remember anything more till I found myself at the station-house—this is my watch, chain, and seals.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know when, where, or How you lost your watch, chain, and seals? A. No—they ought to havt been in my pocket—I went to the Duke on Horseback, they tell me, but I never was there before—I went down by a steam-boat.

MARY DAWSON . I am single, and live in Rope-yard-rails, Woolwich—I was in the Duke on Horseback on the evening of the 4th of Aug.—I saw the prosecutor and the two prisoners—they all came in together—a pot of beer was called for, and the two prisoners shoved the prosecutor against the fire-place—they came away from him directly, and his right-hand pocket was tamed inside out—Pitcher then went back again to him and took bis watch-guard off his neck, and his watch out of his pocket and put into his own—the two prisoners were then going out, and they said to another marine who wat there," Come on"—he said,"Indeed I won't"—the prisoners went out, and I never saw them again till they were at the station—the prosecutor stopped till Mr. Harris came and fetched him.

Cross-examined. Q. How came you to be there? A. I went to have a pint of beer, the same as anybody else might—both the prisoners put the pro
secutor to the fire-place—it was Pitcher took the watch—they were all drunk—the pot-boy was there, but he did not see what I did—I beard Pitcher tell the Magistrate that the pot-boy said when he went out, "Well, Pitcher, I hope you will remember an old friend when you come back"—the pot-boy was examined—he is not here.

JOHN MARSH . I am waiter at the Duke on Horseback. On Tuesday, the 4th of Aug., I saw the prosecutor there—Pitcher and two or three more were there—I do not recollect seeing Graham—I went into the tap-room when a pot of beer was called for by the prosecutor—I took it in, and was waiting for the money—Pitcher said the prosecutor would pay me, and if he did not he would—I went out for another party, and when I returned I found the prosecutor on his back, on the floor against the door—Pitcher was coming out of the door—I said to him, "Bill, don't go away, pay me for the pot of beer; you said you would"—he said, "I will pay you for the pot of beer, Jack"and he gave me 4d. worth of halfpence—when I went in with the pot of beer the prosecutor had some seals hanging down in front of him, and a chain round his neck—when I went in with a pint of beer afterwards I missed the chain and seals—I told my master.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe you let them all go before you went for the policeman? A. Yes—the prosecutor appeared to me to be mad—he did not draw out his watch, and smash it on the table in my presence.

THOMAS WILLIAM GILLING . I am shopman to a pawnbroker at Green
wich. On the 4th of Aug., about a quarter past seven o'clock in the evening, Graham pawned this watch—there was a chain to it—I gave him the chain back, as it was of no value—about five minutes after I went to the door, and saw Graham go and join Pitcher, and they went away together—Graham told me he had had a fight, and the watch had got damaged, and it was his own.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you often take such things of drunken people? A. He was not drunk—he knew what he was about—I cannot say he was sober—the glass of this watch is broken, and it is battered.
GEORGE HARRIS (police-constable R 158.) I went to the Duke on Horse-back on the 4th of Aug.—I saw the prosecutor—he was tipsy, and dancing

about the tap-room like a madman, and complaining he had lost his wath—I took him to the station, and at twelve o'clock that night I-took the prisoner! together in a lodging-house in Hog-lane, Woolwich—I told them it was for taking a man's watch—they said, "We have got no watch; you may take us, if you like."

WILLIAM GLADMAN (police-constable R 122.) I assisted in taking Pitcher from the station to the cell—Graham was there at the time—Pitcher said to me, "Bob, as it has come to this, I will tell you where we threw the seals and chain"—Graham came up and said, "Yes, you will find them at the back of the Eagle, we threw them between two trees"—I went and found them there—these are them.
(Graham received a good character.)

PITCHER—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Twelve Months.

GRAHAM—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Eight Months.

1709.
ELIZABETH DELBRIDGE was indicted
for stealing 12 yards of carpet, value 21.; and 1 mat, 10.; the goods of
Archibald Daniel Welch; to which she pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Month.

1710.
JULIA O'LEARY was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 pepper-box, 2d.; and 4 drinking-glasses, 2s.; the goods of
Thomas Elwood, her master.

SARAH ELWOOD . I am the wife of Thomas Elwood—we keep the Foun
tain, in the Broadway, Deptford—the prisoner lived in my service—she came to me in Feb. and left on the 18th of April—while she was with me I missed a pepper-box, a handkerchief, and four glasses—I discharged the pri
soner in consequence—this is the pepper-box and the glasses—they are my husband's—this handkerchief is mine.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. You once had the prisoner and her sister in your service? A. Yes—this pepper-box has our private mark on the bottom—we were in business, and sold these sort of things—I have one more of these boxes—this one has been in use twelve months—I misted this on the 18th of April—I had seen it within a month before that, in the kitchen—this is a common handkerchief—I cannot say to a day when I had seen it, but it was within two months—I had had it about three months—these are ordinary drinking-glasses—one of them has been ground down—I am sure about this one.
COURT. Q. Is there any mark on the handkerchief? A. No, but in locking my drawer I shut one corner of the handkerchief in, and it is cut—here is where it was cut.

JOHN EVANS (police-constable R 190.) I went to a house in Mill-lane—I found this pepper-box and two glasses—I apprehended the prisoner at the same house—I told her she was charged with stealing a quantity of glasses, and other property of Mrs. Elwood—she said she knew nothing about them—she said she bought the glasses and pepper-box, and Mrs. Elwood gave her the handkerchief long ago—Mrs. Elwood denied it.
Cross-examined. Q. She speaks Irish very strongly, does she not?. A. Yes—she did not say that they were Mrs. Allen's, and Mrs. Allen bought them.
NOT GUILTY .

1711.
HANNAH O'LEARY was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 1 cap, 6d.; 1 tea-tray, 1s.; and 1 pair of scissors, 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Elwood, her master.

SARAH ELWOOD . I am the wife of Thomas Elwood. The prisoner lived with me—she came on the 20th of Dec. and left about the 16th of April—she returned two weeks after—I then missed some articles—Julia O'Leary was then gone, and the prisoner was there alone—I missed a handkerchief, a cap, a tea-tray, and scissors—these are the articles, and what I lost while the prisoner was with me.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Are you quite certain about this handkerchief? A. Yes—I know these scissors—I had some of the same sort—this tea-tray I saw about two months ago—I found. it where the pri
oner was living.

JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 180.) On the 16th of July I went with Mrs. Elwood to a house in Mill-lane, Deptford, and saw the prisoner—I told her Mrs. Elwood charged her with stealing a tea-tray from her house—she said she knew nothing about it—I searched and found it—I asked bow she accounted for it—she said her sister bought it in the Broadway, Deptford, fur 1s. 2d.—I found a box, which was locked—the prisoner said c was hen—I asked for the key—she gave it me, and I found in the box this cap and handkerchief, which Mrs. Elwood identified—the prisoner said they were her own—I found these scissors in the cupboard—the prisoner said the brought them from Ireland.

BRIDGET ALLEN . I am the wife of Thomas Allen—I am the prisoner's sister. I bought this tea-tray in Deptford Broadway, for 1s. 2d. t twelve months ago—I know it by a scratch in the middle of it—I brought these scissors from Ireland—I know them, but would not wish to swear to them—there are many more like them.
COURT. Q. Where did you buy this tray? A. Of a man walking through the Broadway, without shoes.
JULIA MORAN . I live at Deptford—tnylritsbantfw a labourer. I know the witness Allen—I was in the Broadway, Deptford, when she bought a tea-tray—this is the same I saw her pay 1s. 2d. for.
NOT GUILTY .

1712.
HENRY PERRY . and
RICHARD SMITH were indicted for
stealing 2 loaves of bread, value 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Pettafor.

PERRY pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15.

SMITH pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1713.
ELIZA PLAISTOW was indicted
for embezzling 2s. 7 1/2 d., which she received on account of
Henry Youngman Buckland, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY —
Confined Ten Days.

1714.
MERCY WILD and
EMILY LAWSON were indicted for
obtaining 2l., from
Ann Sonnex, by false pretences.

RICHARD THOMAS HART . I am a carpenter, and live at the Duke on Horseback, High-street, Woolwich. On Tuesday, the 7th of July, between three and four o'clock, I saw the prisoner Lawson there—she asked me whether Mrs. Sonnex was at home—I said she was engaged—she said she came from Mr. Edwards, for the loan of 21.—Mrs. Sonnex is my sister—I went into

the parlour and spoke to her, and she refused to give her the 21.—Lawson came again, and brought the note produced—I read it and took it to Mrs. Sonnex—she told me to take 21. off the tea-board—I took a sovereign and two half-sovereigns—they were my sister's—I wrapped them in a piece of tissue-paper, and gave it to Lawson—I know Mr. Edwards, and so does my sister—I gave Lawson the 21. in consequence of the note—I did not know either of the prisoners before.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you tell Lawson she must bring a note? A. Yes, I sent her away for it—I will swear I believed it to come from Mr. Edwards—the word "friend" is spelt "freind"—I will swear I was taken in by the note—Mr. Edwards is an engineer in the dock-yard—I thought this note came from the water-works.

CLARISSA MATILDA MORNKE . I keep a Berlin-wool shop, at Thomas-street, Woolwich. On the 7th of July, about three o'clock, the prisoners came together to my shop—Wild said, "Will you oblige me with pen, ink, and paper, as I have lost two notes, and do not like to go back for a third"—she asked me to write for her—I wrote the note produced—Wild told me what to write—I then said, "It is to be signed"—she said, "Yes, 'J. Edwards" 1—I wrote "J. Edwards"—I inquired if it was to be sealed—she said it was of no consequence—I gave it to Wild and she gave it to Lawson—I had never seen Lawson before—Wild had been a customer of mine—she said she wai tired, and told Lawson to take the note—she went away with it, and Wild remained at my shop about twenty minutes—Lawson came back and said, "Mrs. Sonnex will send it; here is your half-crown," and gave her half-crown—she had other money in her hand—I did not notice what it wai—Wild had purchased goods in my shop, and paid me 3s. 6d. for them—I bad to give her 2d. change, which she refused to take—she tied some money in the corner of her handkerchief, and they went away together.

Cross-examined by MR. BALDWIN. Q. Have you seen Wild often? A. Yes, more than once—she is a cripple—I was not surprised at her being tired and sitting down—I never heard anything against her character—she said,'I have lost two notes—Lawson was there at the time.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did not Wild, in addition to what you have told us, say, "Be careful, and do not lose the note?" A. Yes.
JAMES EDWARDS . I am a smith, and live at Woolwich, and supply the town with water—I know the two prisoners—I never authorized them to go to Mrs. Sonnex, to get money for me.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Your name is not James only? A. No, James Thomas Edwards.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-constable.) On the 11th of July I took both the prisoners into custody—I took Wild first—I told her she was charged with obtaining 21. from Mrs. Sonnex—she said Lawson told her to go and do it—Lawson was not present—I took Lawson—she said Wild tempted her to do it, or she would never have done such a thing.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

WILD—
GUILTY

LAWSON—
GUILTY

p.hi: Recommended to mercy by Prosecutor and Jury.

hi.rs: Confined Nine Days, and delivered to their friends, who engaged to employ them.

div1.p:
1715.
JOHN WICKS was indicted
for embezzlement.

SARAH WATTS . I am the wife of Thomas Watts, of the Yorkshire Grey public-house, Park-street, Islington—I ordered some coals of the prisoner,—I cannot say whether I was present on 13th Jan. when an account was paid—I paid this bill of 41. 6s. on 14th April to the prisoner, and he wrote this receipt, also this bill of 3l. 8s., on 15th May—both these receipt were signed by the prisoner in my presence.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You did not order the coals of Mr. Pegg? A. No, of the prisoner—I knew nothing of Mr. Pegg in the transaction on either of the occasions—I have dealt with the prisoner since—he is now in the service of Mr. Wright.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Did you take the first quantity of coals on his own application? A. Yes, to my husband—I do not recollect hearing it made—I thought I was dealing with him—the bills are in Mr. Pegg's name—I thought it was on commission.

NATHANIEL PEOG . I am a coal-merchant at Phœnix-wharf, Southwark—the prisoner has been in my employ several years—it was his duty to deliver bills and to collect money—he did that in his capacity as my servant—he had to keep a petty cash book—this is it—it was his duty to enter in this book any sums of money he received on my account—he was to pay them over at the end of the day, and balance the gross receipts at the end of the week—the book was the cheque I had ou-him in balancing—I paid him 30. a week—he had no claim for commission—he was in the habit of making a charge for beer and other disbursements—they are in this petty weekly dis
bursement book—at the end of the week I looked at the disbursements, teeing the sums he received, and he accounted to me—I know his hand
writing—I have looked at this bill of 13th Jan. 1846—the receipt is in bis handwriting—here is entered in the petty cash-book—"On 13th Jan. 21. 6s. as received from Watts"—the bill was 2l. 10s.—in another petty cash-book here is entered, "On 14th April, Watts, Park-street, 4l."—the bill is 4l. 6s.—he has not accounted for anything in the cash-book on 15th of May—it ap
pears, by the cash book, that there was a settlement at the end of these re
spective weeks—the book is balanced—here is the entry of 13th Jan.—there are disburse
ments that week—they are carried out of the little petty disburse-ment book into the gross amount at the end of the week—that is all settled, according to the entries in the book—the 15th of May is the last time he was in ray employ—he also kept a wharf-book—the clerk could not make out the bill without the price—he would have to inquire of the prisoner the price of the coals if it was not entered—when he put the price it should be the correct price at which they were sold—there is a price in this instance—the entry in Jan. states, two tons at 23A.—there is the same entry in the petty cash-book—that is not the price at which the bill is made out—the clerk ould make out the bill according to the price in the book—by holding the book up, it plainly appears in the book that he has written one price over the original price, in which the darker ink predominates.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. When before the Magistrate you had not discovered any supposed alteration in the book? A. No, I think I discovered it the very day I obtained a warrant against him for a previous case about three weeks after he left—he left on the 16th of May—I applied or the warrant on the 13th of June—there was more than one examination—he was held to bail—I did not discover the erasure till all the examina
tions

were over—I forget whether I discovered it after the final examination or not—he has been in my service twelve years—he did not give me notice that unless I raised his wages 6s. a week he would leave—I gave him notice because I found frequent drunkenness and neglect of duty—he said after? giving him notice that he could not stay unless I gave him 1s. a day more—he certainly did not give me notice—I remonstrated with him in consequence of his being absent some hours—he assumed a very high manner, as if I could not do without him, and on that we parted—just at the end of the time, he anticipated I was going to take him back, and said he would not stay without 6s. a week more—Mr. Moore, my clerk, is allowed to sell coali for his own profit—that is the only instance, for I deprecate the system—I do not know from him that the prisoner had the same privilege—Moore it allowed to draw coals for his friends at a less price than I charge my other customers—he has done so ever since he entered my employ—he has been with me three or four years—he is charged a profit of 5s. upon the pool price—Wickens is a customer of mine—he is adealer in coals, and had them at 5s. on the pool price.

Q. Suppose the prisoner, right or wrong, took coals for sale to his friends at the same price as Moore, would these entries be right? A. No, the pool price on the 13th of Jan. was 18s. 6d. a ton—the price charged in the book is 4s. 6d. extra, 23s., but the price charged in the bill it 25s.—that would make a difference of 6s. 6d.—the entry at the trade price would be right, all except 6d. t if he was allowing 4s. 6d. it would be right—he does not account for the last entry in the cash-book—the pool price here was 16s. then—4s. 6d. added to that, would make 20s. 6d.—three tons would be 3l. 6d.—I had not quarrelled with him before he left—Mr. Moore was constantly seeing the books—I have the ledger here—the entries are Moore's writing—after the prisoner left went to Mr. Nash's public-house—I do not know that the prisoner lodged there—there was a removal of some of his goods—my wife had given his wife some things—she was anxious that they should not appear in a public-bome among his wardrobe, and I went to Mr. Nash's—the prisoner called afterwards, and asked what I meant by overhauling his things—I parted with him under the best of feelings—this might be a fortnight or ten days after he left—he had improved my business—I considered him an excellent servant-after he left some of my customers told me he had solicited them for a new master—he went into the service of Mr. Wright, who took a wharf 500 or 600 yards from mine.

Q. Did Wright commence business there the very day you took the pri
soner up? A. I cannot recollect, but as soon as I became acquainted with those facts I went to my solicitor—a great many of my customers have gone to Wright—some of them are now returning—they were hucksters who came to the wharf for their coals—it was his usual business to treat with thent, and receive their money—I know nothing of Watts—he had not been a customer of mine—I very likely saw Mr. Wright at the Coal exchange on the 21ft of May—I do not recollect saying to him, "I see you are going to be a neigh
bour of mine, and take my late clerk into your service"—I will not swear did not—he did not say, "Yes, is there anything against his honesty?"made no reference to character, nor did I say, "Not the slightest"—he mip have said, "Have you anything to say against him?" and I studiously avoided giving any answer.

Q. Did not you say "Not the slightest?" A. Certainly not—it is im
possible for a man to recollect everything he says—I cannot recollect whether I did or not—it was after that I discovered this—the prisoner's brother called on me on a Saturday.

Q. Did not you say to him, "I should not have cared where he had gone, if he had not gone to that white-livered son of a b----, Wright?" A. I did not, it is not language I should have used—he came to beg his brother off—I said nothing of the sort.

Q. Did you say, "He will get half my connection, keep him till he gets the remainder, and then turn Wicks about his business?" A. I recollect no
thing of the kind—I cannot swear it did not pass, but I think it very unlikely—I forget whether I saw hhn on the 6th of July.

Q. Did you say to him at the Southwark police-court," I suppose I shall hear again of what I said about your brother and Wright?" A. No, I do not recollect seeing the brother there—I certainly did not say so to him—I will not swear he was not there—I will not undertake to swear whether I said so or not
COURT. Q. Was it Moore's privilege to be charged 5s. profit, taking the larger profit himself f A. Yes—the prisoner in this instance would have rather a less profit.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Is there an account opened for Wicks in your ledger? A. Yes—my clerk opened it for his more immediate guidance—this entry is in Moore's writing in the ledger—the amount entered to Wicks on the 13th of Jane is exactly the same as the prisoner has accounted for in the cash-book—I had daily opportunities of seeing these entries.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When the prisoner came into your employ, did he claim the advantage of selling coals? A. He did not—I should not have allowed it—till I got to the Police-court I had no notion of any such claim—he did not receive money from the customers generally, only from the hucksters—I have no opportunity of knowing what customers he intro
duced—when Moore came to me I agreed to allow him this privilege, as he had several connexions in the docks—the prisoner entered his dis
bursements in a book—I gave him into custody simply on discovering these defalcations—when I had the conversation with Mr. Wright I had not made the dis
covery—the entries in the ledger were made from his book—I have never said that he was honest since I found out this—the ledger is in Moore's writing—if there was an error in the prisoner's book it would go through the whole of the books.

WILLIAM MOORE . I am clerk to Mr. Pegg. On the 15th of May I received 3l. from the prisoner, on account of Mr. Watts—it was just as he was about leaving—I made out the whole of these bills—I had a conver
sation with the prisoner in one instance as to the price to be charged in one of these bills—I think it was the 2l. 10s. in Jan.—I know it was one of these tiiree—he came into the counting-house and asked me to make out the bill for the amount in the journal not to appear the same as the bill—no one but ourselves were present—he told me the amount to put in the bill, as it is made out 25s.—I made no observation to him—I made out the bill at 25s. per ton, leaving of course the journal the same—I did not make any alter
ation in the journal—I made it out accurately, without reference to the journal 1 had the journal before me—I had let the amount in the journal appear less—I understood he was to charge the customer one price, and account for another—there have been some bills made out before for his immediate friends, 1 believe, where he would have charged the customer more than he paid him
self—I was aware of jt—as a fellow clerk I thought as they were his friends he might get 1s. or 2s. by them—I had no directions from Mr. Pegg to do so—whatever he chose to charge his own friends was no matter of mine—I did not communicate it to Mr. Pegg—I cannot remember whether the fair and proper charge was paid to the employer—there is a much lower price—it

might just have remunerated at the trade price—the price in the bill was not raised to give him a premium above the proper price, but reduced so as to gire him the benefit—I have allowed very few of these transactions.

Q. Look at this entry to Mr. Watts in this page, did you look at it when you made out the bill? A. No—I posted it from here into the journal—it was decidedly not in this state at the time I posted it—I made it in the ledger as I found it—if it had been 23s., as it is here, I should have entered it so—it first went to the sundries account—the account was not opened then—I cannot say whether there has been anything under this figure—I posted this entry—(looking at one)—the prisoner told me the price—I originally had 26s.—it was the price he told me when he asked me to make the bill out—it was merely to make it for 25s., which I did, and at that time he told me to make an alteration here in the book—I cannot remember when it was—I cannot find the lesser amount—the entry is correct—it is 2l. 6s.—the price I is added since I posted it—the next entry is 23s. to another party—I do not know anything about any erasure—here is 23s. put to the entry—it was not here at. first—it is Wicks' entry.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. You have made out many bills for Wicks, at larger prices for his friends? A. Yes—those accounts were entered in the ledger—I entered the short price in some few instances—it is impossible to say How many, perhaps half a dozen—there is an account of his ex
tending over more than twelve months—that is not kept the same as my ac
count—the parties to whom the coals were sent is entered in Wicks's account—he is made debtor to his master in the ledger, but is different to mine—in some instances the party who bad the coals is stated in the margin—that is after I certain time—in the earlier part of his account the parties are not named that is thesame as my account—the accounts are balanced from July, 1843, to the present time—Mr. Pegg could refer to these accounts at any time.

MR. BALLANTINE. Q. There is a debtor and creditor account to the pri
soner in the ledger; what is the reason of that? A. My first inducement to put his name was, there was a dispute with him about an order that came through some friend in some way which remained unpaid some time—the prisoner disputed as to having any knowledge of it—this account enables us to refer to parties he recommended—there is no other object in it—I had no authority to make any abatement to him—he never said he was entitled to abatement—he asked me to alter the bills as a matter of favour—Watts's name does not appear in the prisoner's account—if I do not receive an order myself I ask the prisoner what price he sold coals at—I enter the price he tells meii the journal—he made no claim to have them at a lower price—this 23s. the wharf-book must have been put there since I copied the entry into tbc journal—if he was entitled to the deduction there would be no object is making the alteration—no such arrangement existed with the prisoner.
COURT. Q. How do you enter when you are allowed 5s. profit by your master? A. The price I am to pay myself, not that which is charged to the customer.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You had a right to charge the customer anything you pleased? A. Certainly.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know of any dealings with Watts except the three items named? A. They are the only transactions.

MR. CLARKSON to MR. PEGG. Q. Did you say to the prisoner, about the time Moore was married, that Moore was indebted to you 57l.; that he was going to be married with your money, and you should close the account both with Moore and himself? A. Certainly not, nor anything like it.
COURT to NATHANIEL MOORE. Q. Do your observations respecting putting
down a different sum to what was received on the prisoner's application, apply to the three entries? A. Only to one, and I think it was the first.
NOT GUILTY .

1716.
JOHN WICKS was again indicted
for stealing 2 sovereigns and 2 half-sovereigns, the monies of
Nathaniel Pegg.

JOHN WARE . I am a wheelwright, living in Glasshouse-yard, Aldersgate-street. In April last I ordered fourteen tons of coals of the prisoner—the-price was to be 22s. 6d.—I am not at all acquainted with the prisoner—they were to be sent on the following Thursday or Friday—they came with these vender's tickets, which are dated 17th April—I gave the order direct to the prisoner at the prosecutor's wharf—the check produced was given for the fourteen tons of coals—it is drawn by my father, and it is made out to Messrs. Pegg and Co.—it was given to Alfred James, who is in Mr. Pegg's service—this bill was delivered previously; I do not know who by—I think the boy brought it the day before, and said if the money was paid the following day five per cent would be allowed—the amount is 15l. 15s.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What is the date of the check? A. The 16th of May—before the transaction we had a van for sale—we had had no dealings with Mr. Pegg at that time, and knew nothing about him—the prisoner came with a man named Wickens, who purchased the van—I should think that was a year and a half before I bought these coals—I cannot recollect whether I asked 50l. for the van.

Q. Did you afterwards agree to take 43l. or 42l., and to give Wickens an order for ten tons of coals? A. I gave him an order for ten tons, which I received from Mr. Pegg—Wickens was the retail dealer, I believe—from that time I ordered coals at the same place—the bill for those coals was delivered to Wickens, not to us—I ordered the coals in question at Mr. Pegg's counting-house—I never had any dealings with Pegg till the dealing about the van.
Mr. BALLANTINE. Q. With whom did you deal for these coals? A. Mr. Pegg—I knew nobody else.

ALFRED JAMES . I am clerk to Mr. Pegg. I called on Mr. Ware with a hill, 15l. 15s., for these coals, by the prisoner's desire—he told me if Mr. Ware would give me a check I was to take off five per cent, discount—I left the bill on the Thurday, and got the check on Saturday—I changed it, and received 2 5l. notes, and the rest in silver—I gave the whole to the prisoner—in the course of the day he gave me 5s., for my trouble in getting the money—I have collected for him on several occasions—he once before paid me for collecting from the same party—that was the only transaction he paid me for, to the best of my belief—I showed the check to the prisoner, and got the money for it, by his desire.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Had Moore the check in his hand some time before you got the money? A. Not that I am aware of—he was in the office—I do not believe he had it—he could see the transaction—he wag not present when the prisoner sent me for the account, but he was when I showed the prisoner the check, not at the time he told me to get it changed that was five or six minutes after—I think I can swear he was not present he saw the check—I cannot swear he did not have it for an hour—he knew I was going first, and knew I had been the day before—the bill was made on one of Mr. Pegg's invoices—(looking at the ledger)—there is the name of Ware in this account—I never heard anything about the van—I collected one or two hills for clover for the prisoner—I received nothing for that—the 5s. was for the whole—Moore knew I had the 5s.

COURT. Q. Did Moore know the whole of the transaction? A. Yei, I believe so—he knew I went for the account, and that I got the check—I believe he was present when I was sent to get it changed, but I am not cer
tain—he did not appear to make any entry of the transaction at the time—I told him afterwards that I had received the 5s.—it might take me an hour and a half or three quarters to collect the money for the clover.
WILLIAM MOORE . I remember nothing of this transaction of the check, of the money received for it—the whole was not paid over to my master—I never saw the check.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you prepared to swear you never saw that check? A. I am—the boy told me, a day or two after the transaction, tint he had had the 5s.—I have been present during his examination—I swear distinctly I never had the check in my hands—I never heard the prisoner tell him to get it cashed—I knew he was in the habit of receiving profit on a few customers whom he introduced—I had nothing to do with it—he made bills out himself unknown to me—I may have been a party to six or sera such transactions—it is impossible to say it is not a dozen—it has extended over a long time—I have no idea How many—Mr. Ware's name appears in our books, certainly not in the ledger, it is in the journal—these coals are charged in the ledger to Wickens—he is a retailer—we never carted any for him but once—we charge him so much—I did not go to the public-home, and have a jolly drink over this transaction—I will swear that.

COURT. Q. Are we to understand that in this transaction Wickens's naoe appeared as the purchaser? A. Yes—we trusted Wickens, not Ware—we allowed Wickens to make what he could above 5s, on the pool price.
NOT GUILTY .

1717.
ELLEN FINNIGAN and
JOHANNA GRIFFIN were indicted for
unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin; to which

FINNIGAN pleaded
GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

SARAH EMERY . I am the wife of Mr. Emery, a publican, of Gravel-lane, Southwark. On Wednesday, the 8th of July, the prisoner Finnigan came for half a pint of porter, which came to a penny—she gave me a sixpence—I gave her 5d. in copper, and put the sixpence into the till—there was a half-crown there—she went out of the shop and a policeman came in immediately—I took the sixpence out of the till, and gave it to him—he told me to mark it—I saw nothing of the other prisoner.

JOHN HENRY HOLLAND . I am shopman to Mr. Wither's, of Blackfriars-road. The prisoner Finnigan came to my master's shop for half an ounce of tea and I quarter of a pound of sugar on the 8th of July—I served her—it came to 2 3/4 d—she gave me a bad sixpence—I gave her the change, and she left the shop—I had the sixpence in my hand when the policeman came in—it tad not been out of my hand—I marked it, and gave it to him.

THOMAS WEST (policeman.) On the 8th of July I was in company will Whitlam, in plain clothes, in High-street, in the Borough. I saw both tin prisoners in company, walking and talking together—I followed them, fist into the Ram public-house, Borough-market—I saw them come out again and followed them to another public-house—Finnigan went into Mr. Emery's the other prisoner stood about twenty yards past the door—I remained outsit I until Finnigan came out—I then went into the house, and received a I I from Mrs. Emery—I came into the street, and saw both the prisoners on the curb-stone, about thirty yards from the house, round the corner—they

were handing something from one to the other—I saw the hands go from one to the other—I saw nothing pass—they then got up, and went to Withers'a shop in the Blackfriars-road—as they passed the door I saw the hand of one pass to the other, at the door—Griffin handed something to Finnigan; then Finnigan went into the shop—Griffin remained round the corner—Finnigan came out, and joined her—I followed them into the Westminster-road, to another public-bouse, and took them—I found 13d., in copper on Finnigan, and 13 1/2 d. in copper, and a 4d. piece, was found on Griffin—I followed them from seven till nine o'clock—they were both together the whole time

JOHN WHITLAM (policeman.) I was with West on the 8th of July, and saw Finnigan come out of Withers's shop—I went in, and received a sixpence from Holland—Finnigan was searched, and a good shilling and a penny found on her, with some tea and sugar.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These sixpences are both counterfeit, and both cast in the same mould.

JOHN WHITLAM
re-examined. There was no place where Finnigan could have got rid of the copper—she never spoke to any other person.

GRIFFIN—
GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1718.
JOHN SMITH and
EDWARD BROWN were indicted for
a like offence.
MESSRS. SCRIVEN and CLAKKSON conducted the Prosecution.

SAMUEL COULBER . I keep the Ship and Mermaid public-house, Snow's-fields, Bennondsey. On Sunday, the 28th of June, about half-past tea o'clock in the morning, my house was closed—I heard a knock at the door, and on opening it the two prisoners came in—I asked what they wanted—they said they were travellers, and wanted refreshment—I said, "What I" they said, "Half-a-quartern of gin"—they came to the bar and I served them—it came to 2d.—they gave me half-a-crown—I gave them 2s. 4s.—I did not notice that the half-crown was bad till five minutes after they wcrt gone—I had put it into my pocket—I had no other money there—I then con
cealed it in my bed-room, in a pewter sugar
bason on the sideboard—nobody but my son was in the house at the time they came in—he did not see what I did with the half-crown—it remained in the bason till the following Sunday—I never told anybody of its being in the bason—oo Sunday, the 5th of July, about ten o'clock, the two prisoners again knocked at my side door—I was watching for them, expecting them—I looked through the window, saw they were the same men, and let them in—they asked for half-a-quartern of gin and laid down half-a-crown—I took it up, drew the gin, and said, "This is a bad half-crown; you gave me one, you smashers and coiners, this day week"—they wanted me to give it them back—I kept it, called for a constable, and bolted both my doors—before the constable came the prisoner Brown said he would knock my by head off if I did not give him the bad half-crown, and he would give me a good one for it—I refused—shortly after
wards a constable came in, and he sent for another—when he came I gave the prisoners in charge, and said I had taken another bad half-crown of them that day week—they did not deny having been there—one of them, I do not know which, said, "It was not a bad half-crown I gave you, it was a bad shilling"—I sent my son for the half-crown, and told him where to find it—I give them both to the policemen—they were both marked in my pretence.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Did you speak to anybody about the first half-crown? A. No, I kept it in my pocket about half an hour—I did not let anybody else into the house that morning untill one o'clock—I had not many customers that afternoon—I had not seen the prisoners before—I

am certain they were the same parties that came on the next Sunday—they did not say "It was not a bad half-crown no more than a bad shilling" they called me bad names—Smith threw down the half-crown the first time, Brown the second—it was before one o'clock on the 28th that I put the half-crown into the bason, before I opened my house.

GEORGE SAMUEL COULBER . On the 5th of July my father called me to the bar to fetch a bad half-crown out of a sugar-bason on the sideboard, in hi bed-room—I found it there, brought it down, and gave it to him.

WILLIAM RANDLE (policeman.) On Sunday, the 5th of July, I wasieot for to Mr. Coulber's house, and found the prisoners there—I took them—another constable was sent for—I found 2s. 4d. in good money on Brown—I received these two half-crowns from Coulber, which I produce—they were marked in my presence—I heard Smith say he gave Coulberi shilling the Sunday before—Coulber had said it was a half-crown.

ROBERT WOOD (policeman.) I was called into Mr. Coulber's—I searched Smith and found two shillings, two 4d. pieces, and 1 1/2 d. on him—Coulber said, "I give these men in custody, they came here this day week and gave me a bad half-crown"—Smith said "It was not a bad half-crown) it wasabad shilling"—I am sure those were his words.
JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of counterfeit coin—these half-crowns are both counterfeit, and both cast in the same mould.

SMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 27.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

1719.
JOHN WILSON,
MARY ANN JONES , and
JAMES LLOYD were indicted for
a like offence.

MARY LEARY . I am a fruit-seller, and live in New-court, White-street, Southwark. On Friday evening, the 10th of July, between nine and ten o'clock, I was selling fruit in the Dover-road, and saw the prisoner Wilson and another man, who I believe to be Lloyd—Wilson wore a cap, and the other a hat-Wilson said, "What have you got there, old lady?"—I said, "Gooseberries"—he said, "Will you give me a pennyworth?" which I did, and he gave me a shilling—I said, "Is that a good shilling?"—he said, "Oh yes, it is"—I said, "If it is not, why do youk'give it to an old woman like me?"—Lloyd wu standing by the stall near him at the time—I gave them lie?, and they went away—I put the shilling between my teeth, took it out, and had it in my hand when West, the policeman, came up—I gave it him, and he took it away.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did not you say at first that Wilson was not the man? A. No—I am sure of that—I was asked if I knew the man—I looked at him, and said, "Why, he wore a cap"—I swore to bin when he had a cap on—I did not when he had a hat on—he wore a cap at the stall—when I saw him again he had nothing on—the policeman put a cap of him, and I said, "That is the man"—the shilling had not been out of hand till the policeman had it.

THOMAS WEST (policeman).
