On the 10th July, about nine o'clock into evening, I was in company with Whitlam, at Newington Causeway, andsif the three prisoners walking and talking together—we followed them—we saw them near St. George's Church—I lost sight of them for a minute, and thea saw Lloyd and Jones standing at the corner of the Church, about ten yards from Leary's stall, in view of it, and Wilson at the stall—I crossed over on the same side of the way, and saw Lloyd pass and repass, and stand about two yards from the stall—when Wilson left the stall he followed him—I went up to the stall, and Leary gave me a shilling, which I produce—I then went to
wards wards

the Town-hall, in the Borough, and saw the three prisoners walking in company—this was about four minutes after I left the stall—I saw them James and Lloyd came back again, and Wilson was waiting ten or fifteen yards from a stall in High-street, but the cabs came in my way, and I lost sight of him—I saw Jones and Lloyd go towards the stall—I did not see them arrive at it—I kept my eye on Wilson—I did not take the prisoners in charge till next night.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not Wilson fifteen yards from the first stall? A. At first—Jones and Lloyd might be ten or fiteen yards, I cannot say which—I was about ten yards off, on the opposite side of the way—Lloyd and Jones were looking towards the stall—Lloyd ran by the stall, returned, and stood about two yards from it, with his hands in his waistcoat pocket—I saw them together afterwards, but did not see them join company—I did not see Wilson near the second stall, nor the others at it—they went towards it—I lost sight of Wilson while they were going towards it.

MARY BRIAN . I keep a fruit-stall, and live in Maypole-alley, Southwark. On the evening of 10th July, the prisoner Jones cametomeandasked for a halfpennyworth of gooseberries, which I gave her—shegave me a shilling, and I gave her elevenpence halfpenny change—Lloyd, I believe, came up while that was going on, and asked me if I had any gooseberries—I told him no, the woman had bought the last I had—Jones said to him, "I will sell you my lot for one penny"—Lloyd said, "you want to gain profit"—Jones went away immediately, and Lloyd stopped and asked me the question still, if I had any gooseberries, after I had said I had none—I told him no, I showed him the shilling, and asked him if it was a good one—he rung it on the stone, and said it was a good one, and he wished me or him had a good many like it—he gave it me back—I never lost sight of it—he went away—I don't know whether he went in the same direction as Jones, because she crossed the road—I did not see Wilson at all—Whitlam came up and asked me what had passed—I went into a public-house with him and gave the shilling to a bar
man, who bit a piece out of it in my presence, and gave it to Whitlam.

Cross-examined. Q. Directly you gave change to Jones, Lloyd came up? A. Yes, I know it was the shilling Lloyd gave me, I had not another—he could not have changed it, I watched all the time he had it, and all the time the barman had it—I bit it at the time I took it, before I gave change, because I wanted to be confident it was a good one—I did not suspect it.

JOHN WHITLAM (policeman). On the 10th July I was in company with West, and followed the prisoners—I saw Wilson go to Mrs. Leary's stall by St. George's Church—when he left it I followed him till he joined Jones and Lloyd, about two hundred or three hundred yards from the stall—at the time Wilson went to the stall, the two others were about ten yards from it—after this, I saw Jones go to Mrs. Briant's stall—while she was buying the gooseberries Lloyd stood overlooking her, with his hand in his waistcoat-pocket—as toon as he left the stall, I saw him take the shilling which had been tendered by Jones, and gingle it on the pavement, and say it was a good one—di
rectly he left, I went up and asked the woman what she had received—we went into the public-house, and the barman bit it—I produce it—I have had it ever since—I went up to the stall directly after Jones and Lloyd left it—I lost sight of Wilson about a minute before they went away—they had been all three standing together talking—my attention was directed to Jones and Lloyd going up to the stall—I produce the second shilling.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure the barman gave you the same shilling? A. Quite—it was not out of my sight.
JOHN FIELD . The shilling produced, and the two parts of a shilling are both counterfeit, and both cast in the same mould, they are electroplated.

WILSON—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Year.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

LLOYD—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1720.
WILLIAM WARD was indicted
for stealing 1 mare, value 5l.; 1 cart, value 5l.; and one set of harness, value 1l.; the property of
Thomas James Mason.

HANNAH MASON . I am the wife of Thomas James Mason, bricklayer, of Wellington-row, Vauxhall—on Sunday, the 5th July, I went out with a horse and cart, and left it at the top of Brownlow-street, Bedford-row, without any body to attend it—I was absent a quarter of an hour, and on my return it was gone—it was in the enclosed part of bedford-row, where there was only one way of getting out—I found them at a knacker's-yard, in Green-street I know nothing of the prisoner.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was there any reward oferd for it? A. No.

WILLIAM HARRIS . I am inspector of horse slaughtering-houses—oi Monday the 6th of July, I was sent for to Mr. Gittens, and saw the prisoner in the yard—Moore said, "Here is a man has brought a horse, you had bete j see if it is right"—I asked the prisoner if it was his—he said, yes—I asked where he got it, he hesitated and said it was left in his charge, and he had had it to mind, and was tired of minding it—I asked him where, he said, it the Black friars-road—I asked where—he said, "At a gin
shop opposite tk church"—I asked when—he said, "Yesterday, about one o'clock"—I said, "The gin
shop 8 are not open then, where have you been all this time'—It j got confused, and I took him into custody—the cart, harness, and pony wen there.

ABRAHAM PERKINS . I am a stable keeper, and live at King's Head-yard—on Sunday, the 5th of July, about twelve o'clock, the prisoner brongbt a hone, cart, and harness to me—he wanted me to take it into my Green-yard, ud wished me to take charge of it till it was claimed—he said it had been lei unattended—I told him he must enter it at the police-station before I cootf take charge of it—I never take anything unless it is entered at the police-station.
JOHN WESTMORELAND (policeman.) The prisoner was brought to tit station—he said he had taken the horse and cart there by way of a loan, to get money on it.
NOT GUILTY .

1721.
ANDREW GIFFORD was indicted
for stealing 3 pine-apples, value 7s. 6d., the goods of
Israel Jacob; and that he had been previous convicted of felony; to which he pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 11.—
Judgment respited.

1722.
JOHN ABRAHAMS was indicted
for breaking and entering certain building within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
George Oswell at St. George the Martyr, Southwark, and stealing 1 pair of reins, value 3s. 1 bridle, 3s. 6d.; 1 whip, 1s.; 4lbs. weight of leaden pipe, 1s., his property and 1 jacket, 5s.; the goods of
Jeremiah Panton; and that he had previously convicted of felony.
GEORGE OSWELL . I am a bricklayer, and live in Mason-street, Old Kent-road—my yard adjoins the house, and has a wooden fence adjoining, six or

seven feet high—on the 13th of Aug., about one o'clock in the morning, I was called up by the police, and found the lock broken off ray stable-door—the hinges were burst from another door—the harness, whip, bridle, and other things were gone—this thong produced is mine—they were all safe in the stable at nine o'clock at night—my house is in the parish of St. George's Southwark.

Cross-examined by MR. BRIERLT. Q. Is there any communication between the stable and your house? A. It is all attached to the house—it is a large yard—I have two stables in it—there is a passage from the stable to the back-door.

JAMES CASSITIR (policeman.) I was on duty between one and two o'clock, I heard a noise in the prosecutor's yard, and I went over and found the prisoner with his head and shoulders in the stable—he did not see me till I got hold of him—I searched him and found this wbiptbong—I found the things tied up in a bundle, in the shed next the stable—the prisoner said it was his bundle.

WILLIAM MILLERMAN . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted, March 1841, and confined two year)—the pri
soner is the person.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite sure of him? A. Quite.

GUILTY * of Larceny. Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1723.
ROBERT HEFFER was indicted for
breaking and entering the warehouse of
Francis Marcus Beresford, at St. John, Southwark, and stealing 25 hides, value 22l. 10s., his property; and
JOHN LEWIS
for inciting him to commit the said felony, and also feloniously receiving the said goods, know
ing them to have been stolen.
MR. DOANE conducted the Prosecution,

JAMES GOOD . I live in Darby's-buildings, Sloue-y-lane—I am a corn porter, but have been out of employment a week or a fortnight—Stoney-lane is in the neighbourhood of Tooley-street, which runs parallel with the Thames—I know Pickle Herring wharf, the property of Mfc Beresford—Weaver's-lane leads out of Tooley street—when you go down that in a straight fine, there is another lane to the left called Brook's-yard, that tuns off at an angle a little way further—there is a door in ftrook's-lane, leading to Mr. Beresford'f premises, and further down you come to a large gate—on Thursday evening, the 2nd of Jury, I Was in Stoney-lane, and saw the prisoner Meffer with a man named Edwards—they went from Stoney-lane—I watched them to the bottom of the lane towards the river, then lost sight of them—I saw then last in Brook's-yard, close to Mr. Beresford's premises—I did not see them do anything—on the next night, the 3rd of July, about seven o'clock, I was on the look-out in Tooley-street, and saw the prisoner Heffief in a cart with a matt named Cornally—I saw them drive down Weaver's-lane, which leads frotf Tooley-street to Brook's-yard—after the cart turned down there, I went and saw it go through the first gate leading to Brook's-yard—I there lost sight of it—it was empty when it weat down—I saw it come back in about twenty minutes laden with something covered with old mats—Cornally had left then—I followed ft—it stopped at Mr. Lewis's yard, Butlers-buildings, New-street—I understand it to be his yard—he does not live there I believe—it drew into a gateway there—I saw it leave the gateway afterwards—Heffer brought it out, he backed the horse out of the gateway—it was then empty—I followed him and the cart to the old Rose public house—I saw him

get out and go into the house—I saw by the light the name "James Barrioger Snows-fields" on the cart—I did not watch any farther that night—the next morning, Saturday, I was up about four o'clock, and about seven o'clock I went to New-street with Malt and Tyler, and saw the prisoner Lewis in the middle of the road—there was nobody with him—I had never spoke to Lewis before or seen him—I asked if he was aware of what was drawn into his yaid on the previous evening—he laughed and said, "Come and have something to drink"—I do not know if he knew Malt and Tyler—he asked us all three whether we would come and have something to drink—we went into the Queen's Head, Fashion street—Lewis called for some porter—we went into the ta room, Heffer came in some time after to the room where we were-we had three pots of porter—they were paid for by Lewis—when we were I five there, Lewis asked if Malt or any of the party were hungry—Malt said he was—Lewis put his hand into his pocket, threw half a sovereign on the table—Malt took it up and gave it to me to get change—I went to the bar and got change—Poore, the barman, gave me change in shillings—11 returned to the tap-room, and gave Malt and Tyler three shillings each, 11 kept three shillings, and the odd shilling was spent in beer—we had bad I nothing to eat, we had more to drink—Heffer and Lewis partook of the drink I—I left with Malt and Tyler—when we left, Lewis asked the whole of tu to I call on the Monday morning, at the Old Rose in Russell-street, where I had I seen the cart go to—I went there, and found Malt and Tyler there, and tk I prisoners—Lewis said the goods were removed some five miles away, nobodj I had mentioned the goods but himself—he was the first that spoke—I do not I know why he told me that—he said he had no money—I was not disappointed I at that—I came away directly—(I do not know what he gave me the thret 1 shillings for—I heard a robbery had been committed there—I did not tell I him so)—I met Lewis again in the course of the week—he said the goods were I not disposed of—he said no more about money—that was the last interview 11 had with him—I told the policeman of it in the early part of the following week.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR. Q. How long have you been a coro-porter? A. Ten years—I work at Mr. Adams'i, Mr. Goulding's, and seven! I wharfs where corn is landed—I was employed regularly about twelve months I ago by Mr. Mark Brown, a wharfinger—a fortnight ago I was employed by Newell and Keane, of Horsleydown—I was at Brown's four years as a labourer I—I left to get better employment—I got 1l. 1s. a week there, and nothing I else, no perquisites—Mr. Adams and Mr. Keane employed me next—we art I not employed unless we are wanted—sometimes I got more than two guise I there—some days I earned nothing—I left his employment—I gave him no
tice—he did not give me notice—I never bad any charge made against men I my life—I have never been in trouble, and was never charged with any crine, I further than having a few words with the police—I cannot recollect when that was—I was fined 2l.—it was for assaulting the police—I have been employed I by the prosecutor a few days—we work from daylight to dark—I was not work
ing on this evening in the neighbourhood of Weaver's-lane—there is one Imp I there—the lane is sixty or seventy yards long—Brook's-yard may be thence length—I went round that way on this evening, and met the prisoners—the were no persons with them—I met Cornally and Collins before them—they were walking together—this was on the Thursday—they were coming from Brook's-yard, and so were the others—I met them in Brook's-yard, which joins Weaver's-lane, about seventy yards from Tooley-street—I went there to watch them—I was not employed to do so—I said nothing to any of t I four—I walked to the water side, stood there some minutes, and returned again to Tooley-street—none of them spoke to me—I knew them—they

passed close to me—they stood there a very few minutes—on the following night I was at the top of Vine-yard, which leads to Pickle Herring-wharf—that does not run into Weaver's-lane—Brook's-yard is a thoroughfare—I did not ask for the 3s. at the Queen's Head—he gave it me and I took it—there was no more offered—I will swear Heifer was there—I am positive he and Lewis were there on Monday—I went there, because Lewis said there should be money given—I do not know what for—I went to get it—I told what I knew about this in the early part of the week—I had part of the 3s. left on the Monday—the last job I had I was employed by Mr. Keane, of Shad Thames—it was packing oats into hogsheads at the Tower—I got 4s. for it—it was ten or twelve days ago—I cannot tell you when I had been employed before that—I have worked as a labourer—I gave an account of what took place to a policeman named Tate on the night of the robbery—I did not state that I was in a privy and saw the whole transaction—I passed a privy.

Cross-examined by MR. NAY LOR. Q. You asked Lewis if he was aware of what was drawn into his yard, did not he say hides? A. No—there was nobody close to me, only the other two persons—they are at large I believe—they are not here—I did not ask Lewis for anything to drink—he said, "Come and have something to drink"—on my oath I did not tell him I was one of the parties the hides belonged to, and he was to pay me—he said he had no money, not that he had no money for them, and could not pay me yet—he hat large premises there—I do not know whether he is a commission-agent—I do not know that he acted under the impression that I was one of the parties concerned in selling the hides—I did not ask him to give me something on account—I saw him an hour before he was apprehended, by order of the police—I do not know Mr. Beok—I had not asked to see a gentleman shortly before the time I went to Lewis, respecting this affair—I suspected a robbery when I saw the cart—I did not say anything to anybody—I never told Mr. Beck that Lewis had sold the hides—I did not say, Mr. Lewis was' a b----rogue, and he meant to stick to the money to my knowledge—I might say so—it was optional with him whether I had any of it—I have no recol
lection of saying he was a b----rogue—I do not know Beck—I did not use' those expressions to any party whatever to my knowledge—Edwards and Collins were taken up and charged with the robbery.
MR. DOANI Q. How long is it since you were fined 2l.? A. Five or six years ago—I have never in my life been charged with felony, or with any offence.

JOSEPH PEARSON . I am foreman to Mr. Francis Marcus Beresford, wharfinger, at Pickle Herring-wharf. He has warehouses near Brook's-yard—Weaver's-lane leads from Brook's-lane into Weaver's-yard—Brook's-yard has several warehouses leading down to the Thames—it is a very long lane; and Weaver's-lane is a small lane leading into it—our inner warehouse opens by a small door near the top at Brook's-yard—passing that door you go a little distance, and then there is a gateway leading into our yard, and that yard leads to the outer warehouse—anybody can easily get over that gate—it is about nine feet high—it would facilitate anybody getting over if they were in a cart—there is a bar across the gateway, which a man can rest his legs upon—there is an entrance to the outer warehouse, which is secured by a staple and padlock—if that staple is drawn, anybody can get into the ware-house, and then into the inner warehouse—there were twenty-five hides safe there on this night—on Saturday morning, between seven and eight o'clock; I found the warehouse door broken open, the inner door unfastened, and twenty-five hides missing—I have seen the twenty-five hides in the possession of Tate—they belong to my master—I have not a doubt of them—they corre
spond
with them, and have two marks upon them which I can swear to—afterwards looked at the bar of the gate, and noticed a graze, as if a man had let himself down by it.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR. Q. Does the gate connect the walls, or is it belonging to the buildings? A. It is between two warehouses—it con
nects the sides of the warehouses—there is no wall, but a gate—there is no brickwork over it—it is eight or nine feet high—we might have had 6000 or 8000 hides at that time, in different warehouses—there were 250 in the pan of the warehouse where the twenty-five were—Brook's-yard leads down to the river—it is not my duty to see the place locked up—I sent a man to lock them up—the warehouse is in the parish of St. John.

JAMES LOCKHART . I am in the service of Mr. Beresford. On Friday evening, the 3rd of July, I locked up the warehouse—it has a padlock and staple—there are gates to the yard—I fastened them with a bar acrost—I went into the inner warehouse and fastened the door leading to Brooks-yard with a bolt—I was not the first there in the morning.
Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR. Q. It is your duty to see it safe? A. Yes.

WILFRED DOBSON . I am in the service of Mr. Bereiford. It is my doty to open the premises in the morning—on Saturday morning, the 4th of July, I found the outer gates safe—the padlock and staple of the warehouse door were lying upon the ground—I did not go into the. Inner warehouse—there is no bolt to it.

JOSEPH PBARSON
re-examined. Dobson told me what had happened. I went to the inner warehouse and found the bolt unfastened—the aides could be taken out there more conveniently than over the gate.

JAMES BARRINQER . I am a cow-keeper, and live in Snow's-fields. On Friday, the 3rd of July, when, I came home, I found my cart gone—Heifer brought it home about eight o'clock the same evening, and paid me It. on the 2nd of Aug. I had an interview with Lewis, after they had been examined at Union-hall—he came to pay me some money for hiring my I cart during the week—I said to him, "I have a summons here to attend the Old Bailey on your account; who was it fetched this cart that day, you of Heffer?"—he said, "Why I fetched it—I said, "Heffer brought it home, who fetched it, did you or Heffer?"—he said, "Why I fetched it, but I sent Heffer home with it," and he sent the money for it—he was consttaty in the habit of doing so—I have seen them together scores of times—they hire of me two or three days a week, up to the present time, and pay me to an hour, whether they have it one hour or twelve hours—I consider Le the master and Heffer the man—when Lewis came he always paid.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR. Q. How long have you known Heffin A, Two years—he is a very respectable man—they have been in the babit of paying me about 2l. a week for the last two years—I always considered I Lewis a master—I have seen him show bills to the amount of 700l. or 800l.—I believe he sells leather for curriers on commission—he looks about fa customers, and then goes to different warehouses to see what they have got I have drove my cart with him to curriers' warehouses to fetch the leather he came for my cart on an average three times a week.

JAMES POORE, JUN . I am barman at the Queen's Head, Fashion-street, I and know both the prisoners. On a Saturday, early in July, between when I and eight o'clock in the morning, they came to the Queen's Head—Good was there, and Lewis—I saw some other men, but did not know them—I wrw I Lewis with beer in the tap-room—I do not know whether Good was in the tap-room—I cannot say whether they were together—Lewis was not by him
self—there roust have been other persons there—I cannot say that I saw

Heffer—I did not swear that I did just now—I recollect it was Good and Lewis—I saw more men there in the tap-room—the bar looks into the tap room—there is a crook in one corner—I went into the tap-room with the beer—I cannot tell How many men were there—I did not count them—I have got other business to do—I cannot swear whether Heffer was one of them—I am sure I did not see him—he might be there and not notice him—Good brought half a sovereign to be changed—I believe he went into tho tap-room after changing it—I cannot tell whether they had more beer after wards.
Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR. Q. Lewis often takes people there, and pays them, and gives them beer? A. Yes.
COURT. Q. Did you ever see him there at seven o'clock in the morning before or since? A. I do not know.
JURY. Q. How many men were there? 4.1 cannot tell—I cannot tell How many pots of beer they had—I dare say I took in two.

WILLIAM LEWIS . I am the prisoner's brother, and live at Mr. Wallen's, a tanner's, Russell-street, Bermondsey. I have seen Heffer with my brother—on the 6th of July my brother came home in the morning, and told me be bad some hides for sale—I inquired what sort they were—he said something similar to what I had there—nothing was said about the price at thai time—I said I was not in want of that particular description of hides—on the following day I met him accidentally in the street, and after some conversation he talked about the hides, and I consented to have them sent to me—I first asked him if they were bis own—he said they were not; he had to sell them for a person or persons, I do not know which—Heffer brought them on Monday, in the middle of the day—I have given twenty of them to the police—this description of hides was constantly in the market.
Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR. Q. Heffer acted as servant to your brother, I believe? A. I know nothing of my brother's affairs—my brother asked me to buy these in the ordinary way of business.
Cross-examined by MR. NATLOR. Q. He pressed you to buy them no more than any other person would A. No—my brother is a commission-agent—he said he had them to sell for a person or persons.

THOMAS TATE (police-constable M 267.) On the 18th of July, in con-sequence of information, I apprehended the prisoner Lewis, at the Old Rose, Russell-street—(Heffer was in custody at the time)—I told him I took him for receiving twenty-five bides, stolen from Pickle Herring-wharf the pro
perty of Mr. Beresford—he said, "The hides are all right;" that he had them from two young men, one dressed in a white smock-frock, and the other had a cap close to his head—in consequence of that, two people, Collins and Edwards, who answered the description, were taken into custody and dis
charged, there being no evidence against them Lewia said they told him that they picked them up one by one at the water-side, and had had them in their house some time—he afterwards told me he had sent them to Wallen's, the tanner; that is where his brother was employed—I took him to the station, went to Wallen's, and saw Lewis's brother there, who showed me the twenty five hides, and gave them up to me—I have known the witness Good some time—I never heard of his being a bad character.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR, Q. How long have you known him? Four or five years—I have seen him occasionally at work at the water side—he showed me the prisoners—he has not given me an account of the circumstances—he said something at the station-house about being in a pnvy, and witnessing the whole circumstance, and theu he contradicted it—there is a privy clnse to the gate.
Cross-examined by MR. NAY LOR. Q. Lewis told you he had them to sell
on commission for two young men, did not he? A. Yes, he told me readily every thing I inquired about them.

JOHN WOODHOUSE (police-sergeant M 13.) I was on duty at the station-house when the prisoners were brought there—Heffer was charged with steal
ing, and Lewis with receiving—on hearing the charge Lewis said, in the pre
sence of Heffer, that the hides were all right; he received them from Heffer to sell on commission; and if he had sold them, he should not have made more than a sovereign by them; and if he had known they had been stolen it would not have been worth his while—Heffer made no answer.

Cross-examined by MR. MELLOR. Q. How many persons were present? A. A great many—there was great confusion at the station—I will say posi
tively that what I have said took place.

WILLIAM LEWIS
re-examined. I got the hides on the Tuesday—he first offered them to me on the Monday after the Friday.

(John Molesworth Thomas, cabinet-maker; James Jenkinson, of York-place, Kent-road, leather-dresser; Joseph Fisher, glove-manufacturer, King-street, Bermondsey; William Jordan, leather-dresser, of West-street; and John Slow, constable, of Bermondsey, gave Heffer a good character.)

(James Murrel, glover, of Wild's-rents, Long-lane; Thomas James Scates, tailor, of the Borough; Henry Rodgers, lighterman, of Russell-street, Bermondsey; William Watson, carman, of Long-lane; James Cole, pump and engine-maker; and William Ax ton, of Russell-street, Bermondsey, gate Lewis a good character.)
GUILTY .—Recommended to mercy by the Jury, on account of their previous characters.

1724.
JOHN GEARING was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.
NOT GUILTY .

1725.
ANN HARVEY was indicted
for stealing 2 crowns, and 2 half-crowns, the monies of
William Coleman, from his person.

WILLIAM COLEMAN . I am a bricklayer, and live at Church-street, Ken
nington. I was coming home from Newington between two and three o'clock in the morning—the prisoner came up to me, put her arms round me, and asked me whether I wanted * *—I said, "No"—she hugged round me, and would not let me go—when she got me four or five yards past the churchyard gate, she put her band into my right-hand waistcoat pocket, and took out two crowns and two half-crowns—I heard it chink as she passed it to another female—she went across to the other and said, "What do you do here while I am engaged?"—I swear I had seen the money safe not a minute before she came up to me—I had had half a pint of beer and two glasses of gin and water in the course of the evening.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Were you sober? A. perfectly—I was doing nothing with the prisoner—I was trying to getawaf—I did not wish to stay with her—I felt my pocket lighter—she went across the road—I did not shake bands with her when she came back—I bad not been on the ground at all—my clothes were not all over mud at the station—I had not been with any other woman.

ROBERT PARKER (policeman.) I took the prisoner into custody—Cole
man charged her with stealing 15s.—I saw no other girl there.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you notice any mud on Coleman's clothes? No—my attention was not called to it then, not till the depositions were
taken—he had been drinking—he knew what he was doing—he gave a straight forward charge.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

1726.
JAMES WRIGHT was indicted
for feloniously uttering a forged request for the delivery of goods.

RICHARD SMITH . I am a tailor, and live in Church-street, Brighton. On the 20th of June last, about half-past six o'clock in the evening, I packed up a dress coat, and directed it to "Mr. Butler, 140, Cheapside, London," and sent it by the Brighton railway—this is it—it was made in my establishment—it is a new one.

EDWARD ELSTON . I live in Cross-street, Bermondsey, and am clerk to Cbaplin and Home. The prisoner came to me, at the Brighton terminus, and said he wanted a parcel addressed to Mr. Butler, 140, Cheapside, and brought this order before the train came in—(read)—"Please deliver the bearer a parcel to come by the Brighton railway for Mr. Butler, 140, Cheap
side—20th June, 1846—Brighton Railway station, London-bridge"—I gave him the parcel—he put bis initials in the book.

THOMAS PURDY . I am assistant to William Clayson, of No, 140, Cheap
side. Mr. Butler is one of our travellers—on the 20th of June he was at Witham, in Essex—I know that by a letter—the prisoner did not bring any coat or parcel to our house—this order is not Butler's handwriting—there was no parcel delivered.
ROBERT BRIOGS . I am shopman to Mr. Wood, a pawnbroker. On the 20th of June, about eleven o'clock at night, this coat which I have produced was pledged at our place by a woman.
JOSHUA REEVE LAW . I am a clerk at the London-bridge Railway station, and live in the Broadway. I was present on the evening in question, and saw the parcel delivered to the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. The witnesses are wrong as to my identity; they say I applied for it twenty minutes before the train came in; How is it possible that I could apply for it before it arrived, when I am a stranger to all the parties?

RICHARD SMITH
re-examined. The parcel was directed about half-past five o'clock in the afternoon of the 20th—it arrived in London at ten minutes past eight, it came by the six o'clock train from Brighton—there was no other train before this arrived, after six o'clock.

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.
(The prisoner had been before convicted of felony, and there was another indictment against him.)

1727.
MARGARET EVANS was indicted
for stealing 2 half-crowns, 3 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the monies of
James Bowler, her master.

HELEN LEIGHTON BOWLER . I am the wife of James Bowler, a hat-manufac
turer, and live at Brixton. The prisoner was in my service as cook. Oir the 28th of Jan. I gave her 9s. 4d. to pay to Mr. Bunce, the milkman—I gave her 3l. at the time—I gave her gold, silver, and copper—I cannot dis
tinctly recollect giving her any half-crowns—I might have given her coppers—(looking at her book)—I gave her 6s. 4 1/2 d. for the butcher as well, and 6d. for some scent, and 1s. for some biscuits, and 6s. 4d. for the butter-man—I gave her all the money together—I think there were three sovereigns—the only silver I gave her was one shilling for the biscuits, and a sixpence for the scent—I cannot tell what I gave her except the three sovereigns.
NOT GUILTY .

1728.
MARGARET EVANS was again indicted
for stealing 1 1 half-crown, 1 sixpence, 3 pence, and 2 halfpence, the monies of
James Bowler, her master.

HELEN LEIGHTON BOWLER . I recollect the 11th of Feb.—I have it down in my book—(looking at it)—on that day I gave the prisoner 8s. 4d. to pay Mr. Bunce—I cannot recollect the exact coins—I cannot swear that I gave her a 5s. piece—as far as my recollection goes, I gave her half-a-sovereign—she had to get something besides—she was to pay Mr. Bunce out of the half
sovereign.
NOT GUILTY .

1729.
MARGARET EVANS was again indicted
for stealing 8 half-crowns, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
James Bowler, her master.

HELEN LEIGHTON BOWLER . I have here a memorandum of the 5th of Feb., of the sum of 9s., for the same account, to the same person—on that occasion I gave the prisoner two half-crowns and some shillings—she was to pay Mr. Bunce with the 9s. I gave her.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Tell me what sum you gate her? A. Two half crowns, and four shillings, at least two shillings, and some sixpences—I took particular notice of the money I gave her that day (because I doubted if the bill was a true one on account of the sum—I expected the milk bill would have been more—she went out to pay it, came back, and brought me the receipt—I can swear I did not give her money to pay that and other things together—I did not give her a sovereign—I know it wa a half-crown, because I took it out of my purse, and gave it her.

WILLIAM BUNCE . I am a cow-keeper, at Brixton, and supply Mrs. Bowler with milk. On the 5th of Feb. I had an account with her—it was 9s. up to the 1st of Feb.—I never received that money from the prisoner, and new gave her a receipt for it.
Cross-examined. Q. When did she last pay you any money? A. She has never paid me any, from the last week but one in Dec.

WILLIAM JESSE (police-constable P 138.) On Wednesday, the 19th Of Aug., I took the prisoner—I told her what it was for, and that what she aid might be used in evidence against her—she made a reply to a woman ifce termed "Mother," that was the money she had lost—she made a state
ment before the Magistrate—this is the Magistrate's handwriting—(looking at the depositions—read)—"The prisoner says, 'I told Mr. Bunce I had loit the money, and would pay him as soon as I could."

WILLIAM BUNCE
re-examined. She told me a day or two before sh lcfr that she had been in an omnibus, and her pocket-strings were cut, bat the did not tell me she was going to leave.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she say she would pay you? A. She said she was going to have her wages, and would pay me out of her own pocket.

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

1730.
SAMUEL LUCY was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, 3s., the goods of
Edward Lucy, from his person; to which be pleaded

GUILTY . † Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1731.
GEORGE PORTER was indicted
for stealing 1lb. weight leather, value 2s. 6d. t the goods of
Joseph Bennett, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1732.
JOHN WHITE was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Edward Langford, from his person; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

EDWARD LANGFORD . I am an officer in the Navy. On Monday evening, the 3rd of Aug., about nine o'clock, I was walking in Waterloo-road, and near the Victoria Theatre the officer spoke to me, and, in consequence of what he said, I felt in my pocket, and missed my handkerchief, which I had had safe about a quarter of an hour before—I have not seen it since.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. It was dark, was it not? A. Getting dark—it was about ten minutes before nine o'clock.

WILLIAM COOMBS (police-constable L 94.) I was on duty in Waterloo-road, in plain clothes—I saw the prisoner, about twenty minutes before nine o'clock, attempt to pick a gentleman's pocket—I watched, and saw him go afterwards to the prosecutor, and draw a white handkerchief out of his pocket, just uoder the gas-lamp of the theatre—he turned, and passed it to three females—they went back, and he followed the prosecutor—I went and spoke to the prosecutor—I then turned back and took the prisoner—he said, "I bave not robbed the gentleman; I have not touched the pocket; I have been with three females"—I said, "I know you have, and you have given the hand
kerchief to them."

Cross-examined. Q. How long had you followed him? A. About twenty minutes—I was on the opposite side of the way—the theatre was not open at that time—there were no other persons there—I saw the prisoner speak to the females—the prosecutor was not above eight yards in front of the prisoner when I told him—the females had turned back, and gone the other way.

CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant L 8.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, at Newington—(read—Convicted 17th March, 1845, and confined twelve months)—I was present—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years ,

1733.
THOMAS JONES was indicted
for stealing 1 pillow-case, value 8d.; 1 towel, 1s.; 1 clock, 30s.; and 2 sheets, value 3s.; the goods of
John Hiatt :
also 2 sheets, value 10s., the goods of
Abraham Luck :
also 1 sheet value 3s.; 1 candlestick 1s. 6d.; and 1 handkerchief, 4d.; the goods of
Har
man Bennett :
also 1 pair of trowers, value 5s. 6d., the goods of the
guardians of the poor of Lambeth ; to all which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

1734.
LOUISA HALL was indicted
for stealing 3 yards of linen cloth value 4s.; 16 yards of gimp, 6s.; 3 yards of ribbon, 1s.; 7 yards of lace 15s.; 9 artificial-flowers, 2s.; 24 yards of calico, 9s.; 4 yards of satinette, 18s.; 1 pair of gloves, 1s.; 2 yards of muslin, 2s. 9d.; and 4 yards of net, 4s.; the goods of
Matthew Corke, her master.

MATTHEW CORKE . I am a draper, and live in High-street, Peckham. the prisoner was in my service for two years, within four days—she was a milliner-Moody told me something on the 7th of July—I went to his house and found a brown paper parcel containing three yards of linen-cloth, and the other articles stated in this indictment—these are them—I can swear to all but the flowers, the net and three remnants of ribbon—this gimp is a pattern that we had at the time, and we have missed such—I then made out an account of articles which the prisoner had had, and gave it to her—I asked her if she had had any other articles to enter, either herself, or from any other person—she told me she had not—that she had entered everything up—I asked her to read over the bill

in my presence—which she did, and she said she had no doubt that bill was correct, she had no other articles to enter—I then asked her if she had purchased any gimp—she told me she had had six yards of gimp that morning—I said, "Then show it to me"—she said it was on her polka—I asked her to show it me, and then she said it was not on her polka, she had sent it away—she had no business with these articles.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What is the value of the whole of these articles? A. About 5l.—she was at liberty to have articles if they were properly entered—she could not serve herself—she ought to have gone to a second party to have got the goods, and had them properly entered—she might go to any other party, or to myself—she had been in my service about four days short of two years—I think she became of age about a week after she was taken—I did not pay her any salary—she was an improver or apprentice, articled for two years as an improver, without salary—before I put this question to her, Moody had told me that he had seen her take a piece of silk out of the shop that morning—I only know her sister—I had a cha
racter with the prisoner—I felt it my duty to prosecute her.

Q. Have you not said you would not have prosecuted her at all if it had not been for an oath you took 1 A. No—I never took an oath on this subject—I was once at Weymouth—I did not there register an oath in Heaven that nothing should ever induce me not to prosecute to the utmost—I found sone one had been robbing me, and I challenged them all in the shop, and madei solemn oath that I would never forego to prosecute if I found any of then taking things—I did not assign that as a reason why I prosecuted her—I Bd not tell Moody so—I told him I had taken an oath many years ago—I did not tell him that was the cause of my prosecuting in this instance—I do not know How came to tell him I had taken an oath—it came out all on I sudden—I was aware that the prisoner's sister is a milliner—it did not occur to me that it might hold out a temptation to a young girl who was working at my place, and who had no wages—it is not usual to give improven or apprentices a salary—we require them to be neatly dressed, but not extrava
gantly—I understood from her aunt, or from herself, that she had a certain sum coming in to maintain herself—I knew her sister was a working milliner—I did not know where she lived—she has called at my house to see the pri
soner, and she might have been a customer at one time—this is the polka the prisoner was in the habit of wearing when going out—it has nothing belong
ing to me on it—this is a piece of calico—this is the portion of silk thatwai cut off from the piece—this is seven yards and a half of lace—there are thing entered to the prisoner in my books—I have a person in my employ named Baker—I did not know that the prisoner was in the habit of having thing, and not entering them at the time, but entering them afterwards—this the gimp—here are sixteen yards and three-eighths of it, and there are only fly yards entered—Moody went to the Parcel Delivery Company, got the parcel and took it to bis house, and I went and looked at it—I think these thing are worth 65s. or 66s.—I heard that the prisoner when she was of age wow come into the possession of property—I do not know what.

REBECCA CHEESEMAN . I am in the service of Mr. Corke. I took spared on the 7th of July to the Parcel Delivery Company—the prisoner gave it—I do not know what it contained, nor whether it was directed.

Cross-examined. Q. What time did she prive it you? A. Just alter breakfast—it was not in the shop—it was in the millinery-room—theretn nobody there but her and me—Miss Baker was in the shop, which is next the millinery-room—I did not go through the shop, but the back way—I be ten years old next month.

GEORGE WILLIAM MOODY . I am assistant to Mr. Corke. On the 7th of July I saw a parcel sent away—I thought there was something wrong, and I directly called Mr. Corke's attention to it—I asked if he thought he had got all honest people about him—I saw the prisoner give the parcel to Cheeseman—I bad seen her come into the shop, and take this parcel of satinett from the shop into the work-room—I went to the Parcel Delivery Company, and found a parcel—I opened it, and called Mr. Cork's attention to it.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you remember having a conversation with Mr. Corke about an oath that he took at Weymoutb? A. I have heard him speak of an oath he bad taken at Weymouth, that he would prosecute to the utmost everybody that was robbing him—he said something of the sort, that that was his reason why he prosecuted the prisoner—I never had any quarrel with the prisoner—she never, to my knowledge, charged me with beating the apprentices when I was drunk—she might have charged me with being drunk—I have beaten Sharpe—she might have spoken about that—I cannot remember it.
GEORGE JOHNSON (police-constable P 142.) Mr. Corke called me in on the 7th of July, to take charge of the prisoner.

MISS BAKER. I am in Mr. Corke's employ—I have had articles from the shop against Mr. Corke's rule—I have omitted to enter them for a day—never more than that—I receive a salary—I have not perquisites on everything that n sold—I have on remnants of ribbon—I have never omitted to enter any
thing in the book longer than a day, to my knowledge—I have seen the prisoner take things, and had them entered one day afterwards—we who are in the shop have the privilege of taking-anything we want, if it is entered—I tare taken them—I have seen the prisoner take things, and she has told me to enter them—I saw her do that on the morning she was taken into custody—I have seen her sister—I heard she was a milliner—I have heard the pri
soner was coming into possession of 100l. when she became of age.
NOT GUILTY ,

1735.
LOUISA HALL was again indicted
for stealing 3 yards of crape, value 5s.; 2 yards of silk, 9s.; 2 pairs of boots, 8s.; 3 pairs of shoes, 10s.; 20 yards of quilling, 1s.; 6 yards of lace, 1s.; 2 pairs of gloves, 1s.; and 30 yards of ribbon, 1s.; the goods of
Matthew Corke, her master.

GEORGE JOHNSON (police-constable P 142.) I was called into the pro
secutor's house—I went up stairs with him and the prisoner—these article were found in the prisoner's box, in her bed-room—while Mr. Corke was looking over another box, I saw the prisoner take this parcel and pnt it into her pocket—she took these boots and shoes and placed them under the foot of the bed—after Mr. Corke had done looking at other boxes, I called his attention to the prisoner's pocket, and then to the foot of the bed.
MATTHEW CORKE . The prisoner was in my service—these articles are my property—I can swear these boots and shoes, and crape, and silk, and blond quillings have not been entered.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How do you know these boots and shoes? A. They bear my private mark—they are new—there are shop-tickets on these other things—I never missed any of these things—I never put any question to the prisoner till I had been told by Moody that he bad seen the parcel go out—the prisoner was a person of great trust.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.—
Judgment Respited.

1736.
MARY ANN DEVINE was indicted for
stealing 1 watch, value 4l.; the goods of
William Stubbs, from his person: and
ANN WADE
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

DEVINE pleaded—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Nine Months.

WILLIAM STUBBS . I live in Paragon-wall, Bermondsey. I was coming home at half-past twelve o'clock at night, on the 2nd of Aug.—I met a female, but I should not know her again—I had had rather more than I should—the woman promised to see me across the fields, and after a few paces she ran away—I directly felt, and found my watch was gone—this is it.

ROBERT DEIGHTON . I am a pawnbroker. This watch was offered in pawn by Wade about twelve o'clock on Monday, the 3rd of Aug.—she said it was her brother's—she wanted 28s. for it—while we were looking at it, she went oot of the shop and joined Devine—they were both given into custody—this handkerchief was picked up in the passage of the shop after they were taken.
WILLIAM PARKER (police-constable M 255.) The prisoners were given into my charge—Devine said she had got the watch from a man on Saodaj night.

WADE—
NOT GUILTY .

1737.
THOMAS COOMBS was indicted
for stealing 8 sixpences and 3 groats; the monies of
George Tranent; and that he had been before con
victed of felony.

SARAH REED . I am bar-maid to Mr. George Tranent—he keeps the French Horn, at Lambeth-walk. On the morning of the 3rd of Aug. I saw the prisoner behind the counter—the till was open, and his hand was in it—he had no business there—I ran to catch him—he got off, and I called the con
stable Goose—he took him—I examined the till, and found it empty—there ought to have been eight sixpences and three fourpenny pieces in it.
Prisoner. She never called any policeman at all; she never saw me in tht house. Witness. I found him behind the counter and bis hand in the till—he threw the money down.

THOMAS GOOSE (police-constable L 160.) I saw the prisoner come any from the bouse—he ran down a court about four yards long and dropped the money from bis hand down in the mud—I found eight sixpences and two 4d. pieces—I am sure he dropped it—there was nobody else down the court—I Wl watched him before he went into the house.
SARAH WEDDELL . I manage the business of Mr. Tranent's house. I had left eight sixpences and three 4d. pieces in the till the night before.
Prisoner's Defence. It is false; I never was near the bouse.

RICHARD ARTHUR (police-constable L 26.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at Newington—(read—Convicted 13th of April 1845; confined three months and whipped)—the prisoner is the person.
Prisoner. I am not the person. Witness. I have not a doubt of it—I the officer who took him—I had known him before—I am sure he is the person.

GUILTY † Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1738.
JAMES ROBERTSON was indicted
for stealing 68lbs. of flour value 12s.; the goods of
Thomas Cooper, his master.

THOMAS COOPER . I am a baker, and live in Bermondsey-street prisoner was in my service—I received information, and on the 31st of when he came out of the bakehouse into the shop, I told him I wanted him to fetch me 2d. worth of milk—he seemed very much alarmed and said, "Now

Sir, before I serve the coffee-shop"—I said, "Yes now"—he turned round and ran down into the bakehouse with his basket—I followed him and detected him taking one bag of flour out of his basket, and the other I stopped him with before he took it out—I asked him what he had got there—he said a little flour, and he had taken it out of the trough.

Cross-examined by MR. BALDWIN. Q. Was not he in the habit of taking goods out, and taking a book and accounting to you weekly? A. No, I positively swear he did not—the bread was counted out from the shop every day, and it was his duty when he returned from the customers to account for it—it would have been fraud for him to take out a pound of flour, unless I or some person gave it him—if he had an order for flour it would have been bit duty to ask for it—he had conducted himself well—he had been with me about eight months—I have no business to know the bag this flour was in—it was brought on my premises by stealth—I know the flour to be mine—it was impossible for other flour to come on my premises—this flour was kept where he could not have got it out, but by stealth—it was kept in my bakehouse—I found 27lbs. of flour in one bag and 68lbs. in the two bags—I could not have missed it.
COURT. Q. Did it correspond with your flour? A. It resembled mine—it was impossible it could be any other than mine—I am nearly blind.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined One Year.
(The prosecutor stated the prisoner had plundered him to the value of 200l.

1739.
THOMAS MACKIE was indicted
for uttering a forged request for the payment of money, with intent to defraud
Henry Perrin.

HENRY PERRIN . In December, 1845, I was managing clerk at Somerset-wharf, No. 58 and 59, Bank-side—it belongs to a coal company—Mr. Gibson is the head of the firm—on the 13th of Dec. the prisoner came to me—he called himself Thomas Roberts, a cooper, of Locks-fields—he asked the price of coals to the trade, saying he had taken a coal-shed there—I told him 1l. a Ion ready money—he ordered some, and pulled out a large sheet of foolscap paper, which was a bill to James Drunkeld, Esq., for cooper's work, saying he was going to get the money—he came back a little before four o'clock and brought this check for 17l. 10s. signed James Drunkeld, on Messrs. Drummonds—I asked him who he was—he said a gentleman he had worked for for years, and he had often taken his checks—I asked him why he did not take it to the bankers—he said there was not time—he gave me the check—I had not money enough—I got it cashed and gave him the full change—he said he had had communication with this Mr. Drunkeld for years, and that he gave it him—I have made inquiry, and cannot find any such person—we did not take the prisoner before because we could not find him.

Cross-examined by MR. BALDWIN. Q. Did you try to find him? A. I watched for him several nights at where the coals had been delivered, which he said was his residence—he gave the name of Thomas Roberts—there was no one on our wharf who knew him by that name—I sent in one load of coals, and sent in the second load the beginning of the next week, after I had passed this check—I did not know it was bad for a week after—he said Mr. Drun
keld gave him the check instead of money—I do not recollect his saying that he would get it cashed, and let me have the money on the Monday morning—I would not send the coals away till he gave me the money—he ordered two four tons—he paid me 5l., and was to pay 3l. more the beginning of the week, when the next load went in—he offered me the check—I got the full change for it, 17l. 10s.—I did not want the check—I wished him to get it cashed—he said he saw James Drunkeld write the check, and he had
taken checks of him several times—I stated that at the police-office—is my signature to this deposition—perhaps that is not stated here, but it we said so.

COURT. Q. How soon after this did you go to see if you could find him? A. I did not know the check was bad for eight or nine days; I then went, and could find no person of the name of Thomas Roberts—after I gave him the change for the check, he asked me to go to the White Bear and take 1 glass of something, as he was intimate with the landlord, Mr. Gabb—I did so, and when I found the check was bad I went to Mr. Gabb audio. quired for Thomas Roberts—he said, "That was Tom Mackie that was with I you".
ANDREW RUSH . I have been clerk at Messrs. Drummonds', the banken' for thirty years—we have no customer of the name of Drunkeld.

GUILTY . † Aged 32.—
Transported for seven years.

1740.
HARRIET BROWN was indicted
for stealing coat, value 18s., the goods of
Edward Grove; and that she had been before convicted of felony; to which she pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 59.—
Confined One Year.

1741.
RICHARD STREETON was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of trow
sers, value 20s., the goods of
William Beeching, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1742.
WILLIAM JONES was indicted
for stealing 1 knife, value 6d. the goods of
William Coyle Dobson; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1743.
MARY DAVIS was indicted
for stealing 1 shawl, value 8s., the goods of
Mary Ann Ferris.

SUSANNA WOOLLEY . I am a widow, and live in Portland-place, Walworth-common; I keep a wardrobe. On the 5th of August, about four o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came and asked me to show her some dresses—I showed her three—she said she would purchase one, and would call in hour's time for it—I put it on the bed, for her to call again in an hour's time and pay for it—after she had selected that one I was putting the others away in a box—I had to turn round to do that—she was close to me—I saw her put something under her shawl—she left my shop before I could rise from my knees—just before that there was a shawl lying on a box, wrapped of with a bit of dimity—she had been standing close to the box—when she was gone I missed the shawl—I know it was on the box half an hour before—other person had come in between the time of my seeing it safe and missing it—she did not come back till the Tuesday following, which was a week but one day—she then asked me to let her see some dresses—I said, only those dresses I showed you when you were here last, only this half-mourning one"—I put her in mind that she had been there the last Wednesday—she said she had not been in the house for three weeks, and then said it was a fortnight—I said it was impossible to be a fortnight, for If not the dresses in my possession till the 4th of Aug.—I told her I had missed shawl, and that she took it—she said I was a lying good-for-nothing creator that I had sold the shawl, and charged her with it—I sent for the policeman—I showed her the dress that she had agreed to buy, and never came back
for—she said she knew she had bargained for that, but it was hot worth the money—I am confident she is the person.

CHARLES WEIGHT . I am nine years old; I live with Mrs. Woolley; she is my grandmother. I was at the street door when the prisoner came on the Wednesday—I saw her come oat, and she ran up the street—my grandmother missed the shawl about ten minutes after the prisoner went—I had seen my grandmother putting some fringe to the shawl a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes before the prisoner came—I was called home on the Tuesday follow
ing—I found Miss Ferris and my grandmother and the prisoner I am quite sure the prisoner is the person I had seen on the Wednesday.
JOHN MALET (police-constable P 235.) I took the prisoner—she denied about the shawl, and said she had never had it, and had not been there for a fortnight.
Prisoner. I said I was quite innocent; I waited in the room two or three minutes.

SUSANNAH WOOLLEY
re-examined. The shawl belonged to Mary Ann Ferris, who keeps a grocer's shop three doors below me—the gave me the shawl to match the fringe—I had the care of it
NOT GUILTY .

1744.
HENRY WELCH was indicted
for stealing 1 waistcoat, value 2s., the goods of
William Henry Hancock:—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Charles Hancock.

WILLIAM HENRY HANCOCK . I am twelve years old—I am at school at. Mr. Ward's, at Clapham—I was playing at cricket on Clapham-coramon on Thursday evening, the 30th of July—I put my waistcoat amongst some other clothes on the grass, and while I was playing it was gone—this is it—my fa
ther's name is Charles Hancock—he pays for my clothes—I did not see the prisoner there.

GEORGE WALLIS (police-constable V 234.) I took the prisoner into custody in Clapham-road the same evening—I said I wanted him for a waistcoat he had taken to the marine store-dealer's to sell—he said he took it off the cricket-ground on Clapham-common—I went and got the waistcoat—this is it.

GUILTY . Aged 10.—
Confined Ten Days and
Whipped.

1745.
MICHAEL HYDE was indicted
for stealing 1 sovereign, 2 half-sovereigns, 7 shillings, and 1 5l. Bank note; the monies of
Charles Beer Simmonds, from his person.

CHARLES BEER SIMMONDS . I am a tanner—and I live in Long-lane, Ber
mondsey—I have known the prisoner four or five years—on Friday morning, the 24th of July, I met him in Long-lane, between twelve and one o'clock—I was a little the worse for liquor, but knew perfectly what I was about—it was between twelve and one that I met the prisoner—he wished me to give him a drop of something to drink—I was perfectly agreeable, and we went together to the Kentish Drover's public-house, in the Kent-road—we went to no other house—we went in there about four o'clock in the morning—I had. been walking about with him from between twelve and one till about four o'clock—we had had nothing to drink—we tried at some public-bouses, and they were shut—he took me a considerable distance, and I would not go any further—we came back to the Kentish Drovers and ordered some coffee—I drank a little, but not a great deal of it—I drank it out of a saucer—I helped myself—the prisoner held the saucer sometimes—he wished me to drink more,' and held the saucer to my mouth—I told him I had had sufficient—if he was inclined to drink more he might have it himself—I had a 5l. Bank of England note,

a sovereign, two half-sovereigns, and from six to ten shillings in my left hand pocket—I did not have anything else to drink—after had the coffee I fell asleep—I awoke I think about nine o'clock—the prison was then gone—my purse was handed to me by one of the pot-boys—there was no money in it—I had received the 5l. note from a loan society—i got of Mr. Hinge.
Prisoner. We had something to drink at Star-corner; we did not go to the Kentish Drovers. Witness. We did go to the Kentish Drovers.

JONATHAN STACEY . I am servant at the Kentish Drovers, in the old Kent-road—the prisoner and the prosecutor came there on the Friday tyohfe ing, about ten minutes or a quarter after four o'clock—they had some doffie in the tap-room—I saw the prosecutor asleep—I saw the prisoner go outjo about an hour and a half after he first came, leaving the prosecutor asleep.
Prisoner. Q. Did we have anything beside coffee I A. If you did it gin—I cannot say—I had twelve or fourteen customers to look to.

THOMAS WILLIAM HINGE . I am secretary to a loan society—on the evening of Wednesday, the 22nd of July, the prosecutor received a loan of 10l. hi a 5l. note, sovereigns and silver—I did not take the particular number of the note, but I received six 5l. notes from the Bank that morning from No. 14,474 in regular numbers to 14,479—the prosecutor had one of them I am certain.

WILLIAM BRIANT . I am a clothier, and live at No. 88, Aldgate—I know the prisoner—on Friday night, the 24th of July, about nine o'clock, he cane to my house in company with somebody else—he purchased a suit of dodies—I cannot state exactly the price, but one of the two persons gave mea 5l., note, and I gave him change—I am sure the prisoner is one of the penony whether he gave the note or not—I produce the note, (No. 14,476)—it was kept separate till the officer came—the prisoner took the clothes—them.

FRANCIS TURNER . I live in Lamb-alley—on Friday evening, thy July, I met the prisoner at the Lamb-tap, in Bermondsey-street—we had a pint of beer—he asked me to take a walk with him over the water, id Wysome clothes—I went with him to Mr. Briant's, in Aldgate—he bought clothes, and paid for them with a 5l. note—I saw the note in his hand he was changing it, he said it was his own—on the Sunday morning to me again, and gave me a couple of sovereigns to mind for him—the same clothes he bought.

JOHN GRAVESTOCK . I am a police-inspector—I heard itiat tne had been in company with the witness Turner—I took Turner, and Be to me two sovereigns—the prisoner had these clothes on when W was tatea—the clothes he now has on were found at Turner's.

WILLIAM RANDLE (police-constable M. 276). I saw the prosecutor the prisoner at Star-corner, Bermondsey, on the 22nd July and on tie July, about three o'clock in the morning—they went towards the Kent-row I afterwards took the prisoner—he was dressed in these clothes that arelie—I told him I wanted him to come to the station, for he was accused of robbing Simmons of 5l.—he said he knew nothing about it.

Prisoner's Defence. I met this man at Star-corner; we went something to drink; we went in a rab with some prostitutes; we came to Star-corner; we went to the Kentish Drovers, and had coffee and some gin in it; the potman had some gin with us; I then went to sleep as well prosecutor; I got up and went out; I had saved the money up of my own.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1746.
JOHN HUNT was indicted
for stealing 6 lbs. weight of bacon, value 4s. the property of
John Dawson.

GEORGE ADAMS . I live with my father, James Adams. On the 16th July, at half-put nine at night, I was in front of Mr. Billing's house, next door to Mr. Dawson's shop—I saw the prisoner and a boy with him—the boy stood by Mr. Griffin's shop, which is next door to my master's, and two doors from Mr. Daw ton'a—the prisoner came and stood by Mr. Dawson's about five minutes—some ladies came into the shop, and the prisoner took a piece of bacoft off the sideboard, and ran off with it.

JOHN DAWSON . I deal in bacon, and live in Church-street, Camberwell. On the 16th July, George Adams told me something—I looked on nv show-board and missed a piece of bacon, it was not less than six pounds—I saw it safe minutes before.
Prisoner. Adams is mistaken in the identity of the person.

GEORGE ADAMS
re-examined. I had never seen him before—I am sure be is the roan—when I saw him at the police-court he was with three others, ad I picked him out.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Four Months.

1747.
GEORGE WOOLFE was indicted
for stealing 2 sovereigns, 1 half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, and 2 halfpence; the monies of
Thomas Withers; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Six Months.

1748.
ALFRED KELLY was indicted
for stealing 16lbs. weight of mutton, value 10s., the goods of
John Crocker; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

1749.
JAMES BROWN was indicted
for stealing 1 clock, value 10s., the goods of
John Lawrence Davison; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Twelve Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

1750.
WILLIAM HAWKINS was indicted
for stealing on the 29th of July. 1 shirt, value 3s.; 3 table-cloths, 4s.; 2 table-covers, 2s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 4s.; 3 handkerchiefs, 2s. 6d.; and 1 apron, 6d. the goods of
John Lee: 3 pairs of stockings, 3s.; 1 pair of drawers, 2s.; and two hand
kerchiefs, 3s.; the goods of
Robert Scrivener: and 1 shift, 1s.; and 2 handkerchiefs, 2s.; the goods of
Jane Bettesworth.

JANE BETTSWORTH . I live with Mr. John Lee, a grocer, at No. 8, Dorset-place, Old Clapham-road. On Tuesday, the 28th of July, about two o'clock, I hung out in his garden two table-cloths, three pairs of stockings, a pair of totters, four pairs of drawers, a cotton waistcoat, a sheet, not a shirt, and light pocket handkerchiefs, and there was a shift in the wash-house—I saw them all safe on Wednesday morning at two o'clock, as I was sitting up for Mr. Lee half-past six the same morning, I missed the articles—I found the wash-house door wide open—it had been shut the night before—I observed a chair by the wall, by the side of the back door, between Mr. Notley garden, which is next to ours, and the Clapham-road—a person could get from there to our garden, and get out by going back again—these the articles—some of them belong to Mr. Lee—this cotton handkerchief belongs to Mr. Robert Scrivener, who is lodging there—this shift is my own, and was in the wash-house—the other things were out to dry.
FREDERICK LANGTON (police-constable V 19.) At a quarter before four o'clock on Wednesday morning, the 29th of July, I was on duty in Clapham-road,

about forty yards from Mr. Lee's house—I saw the prisoner come don from the side of Mr. Notley's wall, directly from the place where some one bid got over the wall—I noticed a frail basket under his arm—I followed him—he went in the direction of the Swan, at Stockwell—he looked round—I fol
lowed him to the Swan—I have every reason to believe he is the roan—I went on Wednesday night and saw where some one had got over the wall.

WILLIAM GLEED (police-constable V 276.) On that Wednesday morning, at a quarter before four, I was near the Swan, and saw the prisoner within basket, going in the direction of Clapham—he asked me the way to Brixtoo, and said he had been sleeping in a garden, but he was glad he had not lost the basket—he afterwards said he had got over the wall at the Greyhound and had been asleep—he did not say he had been turned out of the Grey, hound, where he had been drinking—the basket appeared t ob ef all of some thing—there was a kind of handkerchief or apron on the top of it—on the 30th of July, in consequence of what I heard, I went to Mitcham, and found the prisoner reaping in a corn field—he had his white trowsers and shirt on, and that was all—I charged him with stealing linen in the Clapham-road—k said, "Linen, what linen—I took no linen; so long as you don't take me for a deserter, I will go with you"—he went about ten yards, and pretended to be looking for his jacket—he then set off running—I ran after him about half way across the field—he then turned, and gave me a blow on the bead—I stopped him till another constable came and assisted me—I am certain that the prisoner is the same man I had seen in the morning—after I took him he said he had been to the Dorset Arms, and went to sleep there, andhad left his stock there.

RICHARD GOLDING (police-serjeant V 31.) I am stationed at Merton. On the 30th of July, Gleed told me something, and I took him to a corn field I saw the prisoner there—Gleed tried to take him—he ran away—he was I pursued and taken—he went home and cleaned himself, and then he said bt would not go to military duties—I said it was not that he was wantedfor it was for stealing linen—he said, "Linen, I could soon show you what I I had with me"—I went to M'Leish's, and found a basket and these articles.

THOMAB EMMIRSON (police-serjeant V 10.) I went with Golding to M'Leish's, and found these things—on the morning of the 31st of July Im the prisoner at the station—I told him we had found the linen he wai charged with, at his sister's in Acre-lane—he said he knew uothing abort I any linen, we could bring nothing to his charge

ANN M'LEISH . I am a widow—the prisoner is my brother. On Wednesday morning, the 29th of July, he came to my place between four and five o'clock in the morning, and brought a basket and these articles—he left themand said he would call again in a few days—he staid about half an hour or three I quarters, and went away—I did not know what was in the basket before K went—the policemen came, and I let them have it.

Prisoner's Defence. I came out from barracks, and was drinking at the I Swan; I then went to the Dorset Arms, and had a pint of beer; I went round the corner, took my stock off, and went to sleep; I awoke, and went into the road; I found the basket with these articles; I did not know what was in it.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Twelve Months.

1751.
WILLIAM HAWKINS was again indicted
for attempting feloniously and burglariously to break and enter the dwelling-house of
Thomas Edward Tout, with intent to steal.
MARY ANN SEAWARD . I am servant to Thomas Edward Tout—he keeps

the Dorset Arms in the Clapham-road—about nine o'clock oh the night of the 28th of July, I locked up a shed in our yard, and took the key of the shed door into the house—I was the last person up—the next morning at six o'clock, I went to the shed—I found the staple had been drawn—there were different things kept there, such as saucepans and pans—they were all as I left them—some old coats had been moved, but nothing was missing—I found this soldier's stock in the garden, three or four yards from the shed—I bad left the kitchen window fastened up the night before, and in the morning I found a wire outside the window had been taken down—the lead of the window was moved, and some person had been trying to take a square of glass out—a man could get into our yard from the Clapham-road by a rail that goes across—I observed the marks of some feet on a flower-stand—I gave the stock to the constable—I noticed the mark on it, 1753 0,
WILLIAM GLEED (police-constable V 276.) I took the prisoner—he had no stock on—he told me he had left it at the Dorset Arms, and he had got over the wall and had a sleep.
EDWARD M'GINNIS . I am a sergeant in the scotch Fusileer Guards. The prisoner is a private in that regiment—his number is 1753, letter O.
Prisoner. I was at the Dorset Arms; I was very tipsy, and got over the wall.
NOT GUILTY .

1752.
MARGARET M'CARTHY was indicted
for stealing 9 yards of printed cotton, value 4 s., the goods of
Joseph Lawrence.

FREDERICK MOSS . I am shopman to Joseph Lawrence, a linen-draper, and live in Crosby-row, Walworth. On the morning of the 4th of Aug., about eleven o'clock, I saw the prisoner look through the shop-window—I went to the door two minutes afterwards, and missed some cotton from off the box in the lobby—I had seen it safe five minutes before—I went after the prisoner, who was going towards the Elephant and Castle, walking fast—I overtook her about eight yards off—I asked her to let me look under her shawl—I there found this piece of printed cotton—it is Mr. Lawrence's—this ticket was pinned on it—she said, "Let me go, I have a young child at home"
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where was this print? A. On a box in the lobby—a person must have trod into the shop to have taken it
RICHARD DAVIS (police-constable P 55.) I took the prisoner—I told her she was charged with stealing a piece of print—she said she had nothing to say to it
Cross-examined. Q. What did you find on her? A. A pair of scissors and a book, nothing of value—she was very poor.

(The prisoner received a good character and, her mother engaged to pro
vide for her.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Fourteen Day.

1753.
JOHN ROBERTS was indicted
for embezzlement

JOHN SAWYER . I am a greengrocer, and live in Union-road, Clapham. Major Sheppard resides at Elm-house, Clapham-common—he has two-of three large gardens attached to his house—the prisoner was his gardener—I ever saw him before last July—I met his wife, and in consequence of wkat she said, I went down to Major Sheppard's cottage, where the gardener resides—I prisoner—he told me he had got fruit to sell in the garden, black currants, red currants, aud white currants, gooseberries, and

other things—I said I would bave it, and I gave him 2s. deposit—he said I should have all the fruit in the garden—from the 10th to the 21st of July I purchased to the amount of 3l. 17s. 6d.—I paid him for every thing as I fetched it away—I am quite sure I had to that amount—the whole amount I had was 4l. altogether, up to the 25th of July.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How long have you lived where you do? A. Two months, under Mr. Gardner—I worked before for Mr. Finch, a carpenter, at Wimbledon—I bave been a bricklayer's laboured a carpenter's labourer—I have no account of the sale of this fruit—I took it as I take it in Covent-garden, and paid for it—what I had between the 10th and the 21st of July was 3l. 17s. 6d.—I think I am wrong in that ststemet, it was 2l. 17s. 6d. Is went to the prisoner, after the major had come bow, but I did not know it—I then wanted some fruit, which the prisoner refuted to let me have—I had been there a few days before, and he said there were ax half sieves of red and black currants; and when I went, he said I wts to have the last, and that was all, and be would not let me go into the ganfca to see—he pushed me out, as if I was not to dare to go in—he once wanted me to buy some hay—I asked him to let me have a bit for a sample, that I might show it to somebody that knew it better than myself—he said be bad shsj* stack to sell, and be bad a borse to sell, and Major Sbeppard wanted lit if it—I did not give him a shilling for the little bit of bay—he refused to itf me have it—I have a stable—I did not ask him to let roe bave a few ateos to pave it—I did not say that I would be d—d if I would not do for him—I told him the last time, when he sold me only one half-sieve, that fld pull him to Wands worth, because the agreement was, I should have all fruit in the garden; and the last week be would not let me go I garden, to see what there was.
MR. PARRY. Q. You did not keep an account of the exact smut you paid him day by day? A. No—I hare no doubt whaterer that I felt prisoner 4l. altogether for Major Sheppard.

FRANCIS ADAMS . I am a confectioner and pastry-cook, and live on Clapham-common. I know the prisoner—I purchased about three half
sieves of gooseberries and currants of him—the amount of them was 7s. 6d.—paid him for them—I took no receipt.
Cross-examined. Q. When was it? A. On the 11th of July I purchased 5s. worth; the other half-crown I cannot say when it was—it was at my wn house—I fetched the goods as I wanted them, in the morning.

EDMUND SHEPPARD . I am a major in the Royal Artillery, on half-pay—I reside at Elm-cottage, Clapham—the prisoner entered my service on tto 13th of May, and left ou the 1st of Aug.—on the 18th of June I went ottrf town, with my family—I sent instructions to the gardener in writing.

JAMES BUCHANNAN . I am in the service of Major Sheppard—I was at Clapham in June, when the family left—the prisoner was the gardener—I went with a letter to him on the 30th of June, when I received it—on the night the prisoner was taken he told the constable that he had paid the major 2l. 8s. 3d., and that was all he had received.

The letter contained the following sentence:—"Tell the gardener, and show him this letter, he had better dispose of the strawberries and currants, and vegetables; be can account to his master for them."

EDMUND SHEPPARD
re-examined. I returned to town on the 20th of July—I sent the prisoner a verbal order on the 21st to discontinue selling any
thing—I did not see him for some days afterwards—about the 27th of July he paid me 2l. 8s. 3d., and merely said that was the proceeds of the sale of the vegetables and fruit—I did not ask him any further questions.

Cross-examined. Q. How did this man come into your service? A. I wrote to Sir "William Jolliff for bis character—he bore a good character—honost, sober, and trustworthy—he lived with me exactly nine weeks—I have had nine gardeners within the last four years—the prisoner left me on the 1st of Aug.—there was no charge against him then.

Q. Do you remember sending him away in consequence of a quarrel with the foot-boy, who was constantly bothering him to have the key? A. He was not sent away absolutely in consequence of that down several times for things, and he refused to open the gate I was forced to go down, and the prisoner said he did not choose to be called "gardener," and he did not choose to have so much plague and trouble, and J turtied him away—it was on the 1st of Aug.—I turned him out in the hall-strom—I bad the policeman there merely for the purpose of keeping the peace, the prisoner was making use of abusive language—when I gave him 'riotte to quit, he came up to me and said he thought he was coming in the ifemto of a gentleman, and I was a low blackguard; and his wife came out of the cottage and used the same words—when I gave him notice to quit, he round and said, "I will go on Saturday"—I said, "Of course in that case you will not have the week's wages."
MR. PARRY. Q. You gave him notice to quit on the 29th? A. Yes, "and he on the Saturday—I believe the policeman did nothing towards oat, he only told him to go.

WILLIAM MATTHEW SHEPPARD . I am the son of Major Sheppard—I paid the prisoner his wages when he left on the 1st of Aug., by my fathers direction—on the day he was taken up he told me he had received 2l. 8s. 3d. for vegetable and fruit, and that was all.
NOT GUILTY .

1754.
JOHN ROBERTS was again indicted
for stealing 56 quarts of currants, value 10s., the goods of
Edmund Sheppard.

JAMES BUCHANNAN . I am in the service of Major Edmund Sheppard—I went to the prisoner on the 21st of July—the day after my master returned from the country—I went with directions from my master that be need not dispose of any more fruit—that was the expression I used to the prisoner—he said, "Very well"—he had been selling fruit before, while my master was away.

JOHN SAWYER . I am a green-grocer. On the 22nd of July I purchased thirty-six quarts of currants of the prisoner from Major Sheppaxd's garden—I paid 10s. for them—he had got the currants inside his house, in a wash-house place—they were measured up to me.
COURT. Q. Were these a part of what you had bargained for before? A. Yes. part of those.
NOT GUILTY .
There were two other indictments against the prisoner, on which no evidence was offered.

1755.
JOHN BAKER was indicted
for stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; the goods of
Edward Leman, from his person; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

1756.
JAMES HICKMAN was indicted
for bigamy.

JOSEPH ROUSE . I am parish-clerk of the church of St. Mary, Haggerston, in Burnswick-street, Hackney-road I have a certificate of a marriage which I copied from the register of marriages in that church—I examined it, it is correct—it
